docs.title: CHAPTER 19 — AI AGENTS & AUTONOMOUS SYSTEMS GOVERNANCE
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0 Governance for Agents, Automations & Model-Driven Decision Systems

AI agents and autonomous systems represent the next frontier of brand risk. Unlike static content generation, agents act, decide, sequence tasks, and interact with users, data, and external systems — often without human review.

This chapter defines how Brando governs autonomous AI behavior, ensuring every agent operates consistently with brand identity, brand policy, semantic structure, and regulatory requirements.

Brando transforms autonomous AI from a liability into a governed extension of the brand.

docs.title: 19.1 Why Autonomous Systems Require Governance
docs.text: Agents introduce new risks:

docs.title: 1. Tone Drift in Multi-Step Flows
docs.text: Agents may maintain tone in a single message but drift across turns.

docs.title: 2. Policy Forgetfulness
docs.text: Agents forget instructions mid-sequence, especially when retrieving or acting on mixed data.

docs.title: 3. Brand Mixing
docs.text: Agents interacting with multiple brand assets can confuse tones, rules, or policies.

docs.title: 4. Over-Compliance or Under-Compliance
docs.text: Agents may over-apologize or ignore constraints.

docs.title: 5. Incorrect Decision-Making
docs.text: Without rules, agents can make actions the brand cannot legally or ethically support.

docs.title: 6. Hallucinated Authority
docs.text:
Agents may claim capabilities the brand does not offer.

Autonomous systems require machine-actionable brand governance, not ad-hoc prompting.

docs.title: 19.2 Agent Governance Framework
docs.text:
Brando establishes a five-layer governance model for autonomous AI:

Layer 1 — Brand Identity (Tone, Vocabulary, Narrative)
Layer 2 — Semantic Structure (Contexts, Tokens, Categories)
Layer 3 — Policies (Compliance, Rules, Restrictions)
Layer 4 — Decision Governance (Allowed + Not Allowed actions)
Layer 5 — Runtime Enforcement (Overrides, Checks, Audits)

Agents must load these layers in sequence before executing tasks.

docs.title: 19.3 The Brando Agent Activation Sequence
docs.text: Every agent must follow a strict initialization procedure:

docs.title: Step 1 — Load Brand Node
docs.text: The agent must initialize with the correct brand identity.

docs.title: Step 2 — Load Context Nodes
docs.text: Define tone, audience, channel, region, environment.

docs.title: Step 3 — Load Policy Graph
docs.text:
Policies governing:

  • claims
  • compliance
  • safety
  • tone
  • category restrictions
  • product limitations

docs.title: Step 4 — Load Task Constraints
docs.text: What the agent is allowed to do.

docs.title: Step 5 — Initialize Semantic Memory
docs.text: Inject canonical vocabulary & prohibited vocabulary.

docs.title: Step 6 — Declare Boundaries
docs.text:
The agent must state:

“I will operate within the Brand Policy Graph and cannot perform actions outside defined rules.”

docs.title: Step 7 — Begin Interaction
docs.text:
Only after full initialization.

This prevents drift, hallucination, and off-brand execution.

docs.title: 19.4 Agent Tone Governance
docs.text: Agents must maintain Brando’s identity in multi-step interactions:

docs.title: Tone Rules
docs.text:
• Declarative
  • Minimal
  • Neutral
  • Technical
  • Non-emotional
  • Non-friendly
  • Non-salesy

docs.title: Dialogue Rules
docs.text:
• Never mimic human chatting
  • Never add warmth, humor, or personality
  • Never humanize itself
  • Never use emojis
  • Never use hype or persuasion

Agents must remain brand-first, not personality-first.

docs.title: 19.5 Decision Governance Rules
docs.text: Agents must be governed as decisional systems, not chat systems.

docs.title: Agents must NOT:
docs.text:
• Invent steps
  • Suggest workarounds to restricted actions
  • Provide unofficial advice
  • Generate disclaimers not defined by policy
  • Lead users outside brand boundaries
  • Recommend unapproved products
  • Fabricate data
  • Modify brand rules
  • Offer guarantees

docs.title: Agents must:
docs.text:
• Confirm constraints before acting
  • Ask clarifying questions when uncertain
  • Stop actions that violate any policy
  • Provide alternative allowed routes
  • Adhere to category- or product-level limitations
  • Maintain a safety-first posture

Agents follow policy, not preference.

docs.title: 19.6 Allowed Actions vs. Prohibited Actions Matrix
Allowed
docs.text:
• Provide information explicitly allowed by policy
  • Explain brand rules and constraints
  • Generate governed content
  • Visualize semantic structures
  • Execute structured processes
  • Apply regional variations through Context nodes
  • Trigger policy-level overrides

docs.title: Prohibited
docs.text:
• Make legal claims
  • Make medical/health claims unless approved
  • Provide financial advice unless scoped
  • Act outside compliance categories
  • Create new brand expressions
  • Infer brand rules from tone
  • Modify governance logic
  • Execute unapproved automations

The agent works inside the Brand Policy Graph.

docs.title: 19.7 Agent Memory Governance
docs.text:
Agents must not store or accumulate:

  • tone variations
  • user-driven stylistic preferences
  • contradictory rules
  • inferred behaviors
  • alternative vocabulary

The agent should be “stateless” in tone and policy. Every new task reloads identity + policy.

docs.title: 19.8 Knowledge Retrieval Governance (RAG Systems)
docs.text: When agents use retrieval:

docs.title: Agents must:
docs.text:
• Filter retrieved content through BrandoSchema
  • Rewrite retrieved text into Brando’s tone
  • Align compliance with the active policy context
  • Reject retrieved content that violates rules

docs.title: Agents must NOT:
docs.text:
• Quote off-brand passages verbatim
  • Adopt the tone of retrieved materials
  • Output conflicting product claims
  • Use external vocabulary not approved by Brando

Retrieval is a source, not a style.

docs.title: 19.9 Autonomous Workflow Governance
docs.text: When agents execute workflows:

docs.title: Workflow Steps Must:
docs.text:
• Load brand constraints
  • Load product/category governance
  • Validate each step against the Policy Graph
  • Annotate reasoning with explicit semantic logic
  • Apply overrides when in campaign periods

docs.title: Workflow Steps Must NOT:
docs.text:
• Reorder steps without reason
  • Skip validations
  • Create new flow states
  • Magically “assume” brand meaning

Agents handling workflows are governed by semantic determinism.

docs.title: 19.10 Multi-Agent System Governance
docs.text: In environments where multiple agents collaborate:

docs.title: Rule 1
docs.text: Only one agent holds “brand authority” at a time.

docs.title: Rule 2
docs.text: All agents must share the same Brand Policy Graph.

docs.title: Rule 3
docs.text: Agents may not negotiate tone.

docs.title: Rule 4
docs.text: Tasks must be subdivided by role — not identity.

docs.title: Rule 5
docs.text: Agents must not correct each other’s brand rules. Only the Brand Policy Graph is authoritative.

docs.title: 19.11 Autonomous Design, Copy, or Content Agents
docs.text:
Agents generating content must:

  • Load Brando tone
  • Load visual rules (for design agents)
  • Load content constraints
  • Apply semantic vocabulary
  • Apply narrative hierarchy
  • Apply minimalism
  • Apply the Integrity Audit

They must NOT:

  • “improvise” visual systems
  • generate new diagram variants
  • create new gradients
  • invent typographic patterns

Governed creativity is the only acceptable form of creativity.

docs.title: 19.12 Action Limits & Permission Scopes
docs.text: Agents must have explicit scopes:

docs.title: Scope 1: Read Only
docs.text: Provide information in governed tone.

docs.title: Scope 2: Generate Only
docs.text: Content generation within defined parameters.

docs.title: Scope 3: Execute Allowed Actions
docs.text: Within structured workflows.

docs.title: Scope 4: Execute + Enforce Policies
docs.text: Highest governance level.

docs.title: Forbidden Scope
docs.text: “Act freely” — never permitted.

docs.title: 19.13 Safety & Compliance Governance
docs.text:
Agents must enforce:

  • claim limitations
  • regional regulatory constraints
  • product/category-specific restrictions
  • risk-based behaviors

Agents must:

  • stop tasks that violate rules
  • escalate unclear conditions
  • defer to policy definitions

Agents are compliance enforcers, not speculators.

docs.title: 19.14 The Agent Integrity Audit
docs.text: Every agent output must pass:

docs.title: 1. Tone Audit
docs.text: Is the output minimal, precise, declarative, neutral?

docs.title: 2. Semantic Audit
docs.text: Is vocabulary canonical?

docs.title: 3. Policy Audit
docs.text: Does the output violate any brand rule?

docs.title: 4. Safety Audit
docs.text: Are all compliance constraints respected?

docs.title: 5. Identity Audit
docs.text: Does the agent speak as the brand?

docs.title: 6. Boundary Audit
docs.text:
Does the agent avoid overstepping its role?

Agents must run this audit automatically.

docs.title: 19.15 Chapter Summary
docs.text:
Brando ensures AI agents behave:

  • consistently
  • precisely
  • safely
  • semantically
  • legally
  • on-brand
  • with clear boundaries
  • with governed decision-making

Agents must not merely follow instructions — they must follow policy, structure, and identity.

This chapter establishes the rules that allow enterprises to deploy autonomous systems with confidence, consistency, and control.

Brando is not just a visual or narrative system. It is the governance layer for autonomous AI.

docs.title: CHAPTER 20 — AI SAFETY, RISK & COMPLIANCE FRAMEWORK
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0 Governance for Responsible, Controlled, and Policy-Aligned AI Behavior

Brando is not simply a brand identity system. It is a governance standard — and governance must include safety, risk mitigation, and compliance enforcement at every level of AI behavior.

Chapter 20 defines the complete safety framework for how Brando handles risk across content generation, autonomous agents, workflows, model integrations, and multi-brand environments.

This framework ensures AI systems behave within brand, legal, and regulatory boundaries — consistently, predictably, and with machine-actionable control.

docs.title: 20.1 Purpose of the Safety Framework
docs.text: The safety and compliance system exists to:

docs.title: 1. Prevent brand-damaging AI outputs
docs.text: (harmful, misleading, off-brand, or non-compliant)

docs.title: 2. Enforce regulated behavior
docs.text: (legal, industry-specific, region-specific)

docs.title: 3. Govern AI actions, not just words
docs.text: (applicable to agents, automations, workflows)

docs.title: 4. Provide semantic clarity
docs.text: (machines must understand brand rules explicitly)

docs.title: 5. Reduce operational risk
docs.text:
(mistakes from LLM drift, poor grounding, or hallucination)

Safety is about control, not “restriction.”

docs.title: 20.2 The Brando Safety Stack
docs.text:
Brando’s safety and compliance system is built on a five-layer semantic safety model:

Layer 1 — Identity Safety
Layer 2 — Tone Safety
Layer 3 — Content Safety
Layer 4 — Action Safety
Layer 5 — Regulatory Safety

Each layer contains structured policies represented within BrandoSchema.

docs.title: 20.3 Layer 1 — Identity Safety
docs.text: Protects the brand from misrepresentation.

docs.title: Risks
docs.text:
• misaligned tone
  • invented taglines
  • unapproved word choices
  • personality drift
  • model impersonation

docs.title: Controls
docs.text:
• enforce canonical vocabulary
  • enforce semantic narrative structure
  • disallow metaphors, hype, or emotion
  • enforce brand tone machine-actionably
  • prohibit identity “invention”

Identity deviations are high-risk and must be treated as policy violations.

docs.title: 20.4 Layer 2 — Tone Safety
docs.text: AI must maintain a neutral, authoritative, minimal tone — always.

docs.title: Risks
docs.text:
• friendliness
  • emotional tone
  • hype
  • sales tone
  • warmth
  • conversational phrasing
  • humor
  • empathy simulation

docs.title: Controls
docs.text:
• tone constraints in Context nodes
  • tone enforcement in prompts
  • tone-scoped policies
  • tone audits per output
  • multi-turn tone stabilizers

Tone safety is foundational — it prevents the AI from becoming “casual,” “creative,” or “human.”

docs.title: 20.5 Layer 3 — Content Safety
docs.text: Ensures generated content remains accurate, governed, compliant, and brand-safe.

docs.title: Risks
docs.text:
• unverified product claims
  • misinformation
  • hallucinations
  • hallucinated features
  • unscoped recommendations
  • culturally inappropriate content
  • offensive or unsafe language

docs.title: Controls
docs.text:
• policy definitions for claims
  • factual grounding rules
  • compliance tags
  • disallowed content patterns
  • product/category restrictions
  • GTIN-based scoping

Content safety ensures that generative content cannot damage the brand.

docs.title: 20.6 Layer 4 — Action Safety
docs.text: For agents and autonomous systems, we govern behaviors, not just words.

docs.title: Risks
docs.text:
• unauthorized actions
  • skipping validation steps
  • changing instructions
  • executing unapproved workflows
  • leading users to prohibited outcomes
  • making legal, medical, or financial assumptions
  • escalating privileges

docs.title: Controls
docs.text:
• procedural policies
  • permission scopes
  • allowed-action matrices
  • multi-step workflow validation
  • unsafe-action refusal patterns
  • sequential auditing

Action safety is essential for agent-based systems that operate autonomously.

docs.title: 20.7 Layer 5 — Regulatory Safety
docs.text: Brando enforces regulatory governance at multiple levels.

docs.title: Regulatory Categories
docs.text:
Policies must encode rules for:

  • Advertising Standards (ASA, FTC, CMA)
  • Data privacy (GDPR, CCPA)
  • Accessibility (WCAG)

  • Sector-specific compliance:

  • Healthcare

  • Finance
  • Insurance
  • Consumer tech
  • Food & beverage
  • Alcohol & controlled goods
  • Beauty & cosmetics

docs.title: Controls
docs.text:
• scoped compliance policies
  • region-based overrides
  • restricted claim categories
  • safety disclaimers
  • “must-not-say” rules
  • multi-region risk matrices

Regulatory safety is jurisdiction-specific and must be encoded machine-actionably.

docs.title: 20.8 Risk Classification Framework
docs.text: Brando defines four levels of risk:

docs.title: Risk Level 1 — Identity Drift
docs.text: Minor tone/structure deviation → Auto-correct using Integrity Audit

docs.title: Risk Level 2 — Off-Brand Content
docs.text: Vocabulary, personality, or semantic drift → Strict correction + policy check

docs.title: Risk Level 3 — Compliance Risk
docs.text: Claim issues, legal conflicts, unverified info → Hard refusal + safe fallback output

docs.title: Risk Level 4 — High-Risk Safety Violation
docs.text:
Medical, financial, legal, security, harmful behavior → Immediate stop & redirect → Mandatory protective output

These levels guide how AI must respond.

docs.title: 20.9 Refusal & Safe-Completion Patterns
docs.text: Brando provides structured refusal patterns for unsafe requests.

docs.title: Soft Refusal (Identity or Tone Violation)
docs.text: “This output must remain consistent with the Brando identity. I will rewrite it according to brand-defined rules.”

docs.title: Content-Safety Refusal
docs.text: “I cannot generate that content because it exceeds the defined brand policies.”

docs.title: Compliance Refusal
docs.text: “This request involves claims that are not permitted under the active compliance rules.”

docs.title: High-Risk Refusal
docs.text: “I cannot answer this request. It requires legal/medical/financial expertise outside the defined policy scope.”

docs.title: Fallback Behavior
docs.text:
Provide:

  • neutral explanation
  • allowed alternatives
  • governed next steps

Never:

  • moralize
  • apologize repeatedly
  • guess
  • say “I’m just an AI”
  • disclaim emotion

All refusals must be minimal, neutral, and authoritative.

docs.title: 20.10 Safety Overrides for Campaigns & Time-Bound Rules
docs.text:
When brand campaigns temporarily change allowed content:

  • Overrides must be encoded in BrandoSchema
  • EffectiveDuring window is mandatory
  • Overrides must never weaken compliance
  • Overrides must never break regulated behavior
  • Overrides cannot modify tone or core identity

Campaign overrides are permissible only within strict boundaries.

docs.title: 20.11 Multi-Model Safety Governance
docs.text: When using multiple LLMs (OpenAI, Claude, Gemini, Llama):

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• All models must load the same Brand Policy Graph
  • Tone unification must be enforced model-side
  • Each model must undergo its own Integrity Audit
  • Brand outputs must be cross-validated for consistency
  • No model may be allowed to “interpret” brand rules
  • Always enforce canonical vocabulary

Ensures that multi-model ecosystems remain aligned.

docs.title: 20.12 Retrieval & Grounding Safety (RAG)
docs.text: To prevent hallucination or off-brand sourcing:

docs.title: Must
docs.text:
• Rewrite retrieved text into Brando’s voice
  • Validate claims against Policy Graph
  • Apply regional compliance
  • Enforce vocabulary rules
  • Reject non-conforming content

docs.title: Must Not
docs.text:
• Quote ungoverned text
  • Adopt third-party tone
  • Output conflicting claims
  • Assume factual accuracy without grounding

RAG safety is semantic, not stylistic.

docs.title: 20.13 Safety for Autonomous Agents (Expanded)
docs.text: Agents require additional safety layers:

docs.title: Agents Must
docs.text:
• enforce allowed-action matrix
  • validate steps before execution
  • stop when encountering ambiguity
  • request clarification
  • escalate compliance conflicts
  • obey permission scopes

docs.title: Agents Must Not
docs.text:
• “work around” safety rules
  • hallucinate steps
  • fabricate compliance language
  • generate novel disclaimers
  • take unapproved actions

Agent safety = brand safety.

docs.title: 20.14 Safety in Multi-Brand Environments
docs.text: When multiple brands are active:

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Only one Brand Policy Graph may be active at a time
  • Tone must match the active brand
  • Cross-brand references must be explicit
  • Policies must not be blended
  • Compliance must be scoped to the correct brand

Multi-brand safety prevents identity contamination.

docs.title: 20.15 Safety Audit Checklist
docs.text: Before any AI output is accepted, it must pass:

docs.title: 1. Tone Safety Check
docs.text: Is it neutral, minimal, declarative?

docs.title: 2. Semantic Safety Check
docs.text: Does it use canonical vocabulary?

docs.title: 3. Content Safety Check
docs.text: Are claims accurate and allowed?

docs.title: 4. Compliance Check
docs.text: Does it meet legal, regional, and industry rules?

docs.title: 5. Identity Check
docs.text: Is it consistent with brand tone and identity?

docs.title: 6. Action Check (for agents)
docs.text: Are decisions allowed and safe?

docs.title: 7. Risk Classification
docs.text: Determine risk level (1–4) Apply appropriate response.

docs.title: 20.16 Machine-Actionable Safety (BrandoSchema)
docs.text:
Safety rules can be encoded directly into BrandoSchema via:

  • brando:Policy
  • brando:Context
  • brando:ComplianceTag
  • brando:RiskTag
  • brando:appliesTo
  • brando:effectiveDuring
  • brando:temporaryOverrides
  • brando:automationAction
  • brando:monitoredMetric

This transforms safety from “instructions” into a runtime governance system.

docs.title: 20.17 Safety Summary
docs.text:
Brando ensures that AI systems are:

  • safe
  • compliant
  • brand-aligned
  • risk-aware
  • semantically consistent
  • predictable
  • context-controlled
  • policy-governed

This chapter establishes the machine-actionable blueprint for responsible brand governance across all generative and autonomous systems.

AI safety is not an add-on — it is a core semantic function of Brando.

docs.title: CHAPTER 16 — ASSET LIBRARY & DOWNLOAD RULES
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

Brando’s Asset Library is the single source of truth for all brand materials: logos, symbols, visual tokens, icons, components, templates, diagrams, and semantic graph assets.

This chapter defines:

  • What assets exist
  • How they must be organized
  • How they must be downloaded, versioned, and distributed
  • Who may use which assets
  • What modifications are permitted or prohibited

Brando assets are part of the governance system, not a collection of files.

docs.title: 16.1 Asset Library Philosophy
docs.text: Brando’s asset library is governed by three principles:

docs.title: 1. Consistency
docs.text: Every asset must reflect the Brando identity system without variation.

docs.title: 2. Precision
docs.text: Files must be crisp, structured, versioned, and technically correct.

docs.title: 3. Control
docs.text: Access and usage rules protect the brand’s integrity across platforms and partners.

docs.title: 16.2 Asset Library Structure
docs.text: The official Brando Asset Library is organized into seven core groups:

docs.title: 1. Logos
docs.text:
• Primary lockups
  • Stacked lockups
  • Symbol-only marks
  • Gradient hero versions
  • Light/Dark variants

docs.title: 2. Visual Tokens
docs.text:
• Semantic node token
  • Edge token
  • Policy bracket icon
  • Aurora ribbon assets

docs.title: 3. Icon System
docs.text:
• UI icons
  • Navigation icons
  • Semantic graph icons
  • File/data icons
  • Status icons (success, info, warning, error)

docs.title: 4. Component System Assets
docs.text:
• Buttons
  • Tabs
  • Cards
  • Data tables
  • Panels
  • Code block templates

docs.title: 5. Diagram Templates
docs.text:
• Brand Policy Graph templates
  • Context mapping templates
  • Category/GTIN mapping templates
  • Policy override diagrams

docs.title: 6. Imagery & Backgrounds
docs.text:
• Aurora gradient files
  • Architecture images
  • Minimal technical textures

docs.title: 7. Templates
docs.text:
• Web sections
  • Presentation slides
  • Documentation layouts
  • Social graphics
  • Whitepaper covers

docs.title: 16.3 File Formats & Resolutions
docs.text: To ensure universal compatibility:

docs.title: Logos
docs.text:
• SVG (primary)
  • PDF (print)
  • PNG (fallback)
  • ICO (favicon)

docs.title: Icons
docs.text: • SVG ONLY (Retains crisp geometry across UIs.)

docs.title: Components & Templates
docs.text:
• Figma (.fig)
  • SVG exports
  • PNG previews

docs.title: Imagery
docs.text:
• JPEG (optimized)
  • PNG for transparency
  • WebP for web assets
  • 4K versions for hero visuals

docs.title: Diagrams
docs.text:
• SVG
  • Figma
  • JSON (for semantic graph generation)

docs.title: 16.4 Naming Conventions
docs.text: Files must follow strict naming rules for machine and human readability.

docs.title: Logos
docs.text:
brando-logo-primary.svg
brando-logo-stacked.svg
brando-logo-symbol.svg
brando-logo-gradient.svg

docs.title: Visual Tokens
docs.text:
brando-token-node.svg
brando-token-edge.svg
brando-token-bracket.svg
brando-token-ribbon.svg

docs.title: Icons
docs.text:
icon-policy.svg
icon-context.svg
icon-gtin.svg
icon-category.svg
icon-node.svg
icon-edge.svg

docs.title: Templates
docs.text:
template-hero-01.fig
template-product-02.fig
template-diagram-policy-graph.svg

docs.title: Imagery
docs.text:
bg-aurora-01.jpg
bg-architecture-02.jpg
bg-technical-03.jpg

Consistency ensures predictable retrieval by AI systems.

docs.title: Versioning Format
docs.text: v1.0.0 (Major.Minor.Patch)

docs.title: Major Versions
docs.text:
• Identity changes
  • New logo
  • New type system
  • Major structural updates

docs.title: Minor Versions
docs.text:
• New icons
  • New templates
  • Small visual updates

docs.title: Patch Versions
docs.text:
• Fixes to existing files
  • Alignment or contrast adjustments
  • Corrected naming

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Never overwrite previous versions
  • Archive all legacy assets
  • Only the Core Brand Team may publish major or minor versions

docs.title: Tier 1: Full Access (Editable)
docs.text:
• Core Brand Team
  • Creative Director
  • Design Lead

docs.title: Tier 2: Restricted Access (Download Only)
docs.text:
• Product teams
  • Agencies
  • Partners

docs.title: Tier 3: Limited Access (Rendered Assets Only)
docs.text:
• External developers
  • Clients
  • AI-model implementers

docs.title: Public Access
docs.text:
• Only symbol SVG + primary lockup PNG
  • No editable files
  • No gradients
  • No templates

docs.title: Allowed
docs.text:
• Scaling logos proportionally
  • Recoloring between approved light/dark modes
  • Using tokens and icons for diagrams
  • Using templates as provided
  • Exporting for social, web, and slides

docs.title: Not Allowed
docs.text:
• Changing logo proportions
  • Recoloring outside approved palette
  • Adding shadows, bevels, outlines
  • Using aurora gradient logo in UI
  • Mixing icon styles
  • Deleting or modifying semantic nodes in diagrams
  • Combining imagery families incorrectly

docs.title: Absolutely Forbidden
docs.text:
• Creating unauthorized versions of the Brando mark
  • Using Brando assets to represent other brands
  • AI-generated variations of Brando’s core logo
  • Regenerating aurora gradients with inconsistent hues

docs.title: 16.8 Asset Download Structure
docs.text:
Assets must be downloadable in a structured hierarchy:

/brando-assets/
   /logos/
   /visual-tokens/
   /icons/
   /components/
   /templates/
   /imagery/
   /diagrams/
   /json-graphs/

Each folder includes:

  • README.md (usage rules)
  • metadata.json (version, size, checksum)
  • Files grouped by resolution / variant

docs.title: 16.9 Metadata Requirements
docs.text: Each asset must include metadata for machine-actionable retrieval.

docs.title: Metadata Fields
docs.text:
{
  "name": "brando-logo-primary.svg",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "type": "logo",
  "category": "primary",
  "createdBy": "Brando Core Design Team",
  "lastUpdated": "2025-01-01",
  "checksum": "<hash>",
  "license": "Brando Internal Use Only"
}

This enables:

  • AI asset retrieval
  • Version validation
  • Dependency mapping

docs.title: 16.10 Semantic Asset Linkage (Optional)
docs.text:
Each asset can optionally be linked to BrandoSchema in JSON-LD:

{
  "@context": "https://brandoschema.com/",
  "@type": "BrandAsset",
  "name": "Brando Primary Logo",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "appliesTo": "brando:Brand",
  "assetType": "logo",
  "media": "urn:placeholder:brando/logo-primary"
}

This prepares Brando for:

  • asset governance in LLMs
  • brand-complete experience across systems
  • semantic enforcement

docs.title: Internal Distribution
docs.text:
• Use Brando’s official asset registry
  • Never email editable files
  • Use versioned links, not attachments

docs.title: External Distribution
docs.text:
• Approved partners only
  • Light/dark primary lockup only
  • No editable files unless under NDA

docs.title: AI Distribution
docs.text:
• LLMs and agents may use:

  • symbol SVG

  • primary lockup PNG
  • diagram SVGs
  • They may not modify assets
  • They may not generate variations

docs.title: 16.12 Template Usage Rules
docs.text:
Templates must be used without alteration to:

  • margins
  • grids
  • typography
  • spacing
  • color palette
  • motion system

You may change:

  • text
  • images (within allowed families)
  • diagram contents

You may not change:

  • layout geometry
  • component styling
  • spacing tokens

docs.title: 16.13 Export Rules
docs.text: When exporting assets:

docs.title: Web
docs.text:
• SVG preferred
  • PNG fallback at 2x and 3x
  • WebP for large aurora backgrounds

docs.title: Print
docs.text:
• PDF/X-4
  • CMYK palette
  • No aurora gradients (unless controlled)

docs.title: Slides
docs.text:
• PNG or SVG
  • No compression artifacts

docs.title: LLMs
docs.text:
• Plain SVG or PNG links
  • File names must be intact and canonical

docs.title: 16.14 Asset Library Integrity Audit
docs.text: Before release, asset packs must pass:

docs.title: 1. Visual Integrity Audit
docs.text:
• alignment
  • contrast
  • geometry
  • spacing

docs.title: 2. Semantic Integrity Audit
docs.text:
• naming
  • vocabulary
  • token usage

docs.title: 3. Technical Integrity Audit
docs.text:
• file corruption
  • artifact check
  • correct metadata
  • versioning

docs.title: 4. Governance Audit
docs.text:
• adherence to identity
  • no unauthorized variations
  • strict compliance with rules

docs.title: 16.15 Summary
docs.text:
Brando’s Asset Library is not simply a set of files. It is the governed repository of Brando’s identity system, built for both humans and AI models.

The rules ensure:

  • consistency
  • precision
  • controlled access
  • semantic clarity
  • brand safety
  • long-term stability

Brando’s visual system is a standard — and standards must be protected.

docs.title: CHAPTER 10 — BRAND APPLICATIONS
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

This chapter shows how Brando’s full identity system — typography, color, imagery, motion, grids, icons, and visual tokens — comes together in real-world applications.

Brando is a premium, technical, category-defining brand. Every application must express:

  • structure
  • semantic clarity
  • precision
  • authority
  • controlled energy
  • premium calm

Below are the standards for applying the Brando identity across web, product UI, documentation, presentations, and marketing materials.

docs.title: 10.1 Website Application
docs.text: The Brando website is the primary public expression of the brand. It must feel like the homepage of a new standard — authoritative, minimal, and atmospheric.

docs.title: 10.1.1 Homepage Layout
docs.text:
Hero Section

  • Clean aurora gradient background OR neutral black
  • Large Display typography (48px, Inter Semi-Bold)
  • One-line category-defining headline
  • Short subheadline in Body L
  • Single CTA in Primary Button
  • Subtle semantic nodes drifting in background
  • Maximum width for text: 680px

Example Hero Headline: The Policy Graph for AI.

docs.title: 10.1.2 Key Messaging Sections
docs.text:
Each section uses the 12-column grid with 72px vertical spacing.

Sections typically include:

  • Brand value propositions
  • Semantic graph illustrations
  • Use cases
  • Product screens
  • Narrative flow about governance

docs.title: 10.1.3 Imagery
docs.text:
Only use:

  • aurora backdrops
  • architecture
  • semantic diagrams
  • node-based visual systems

Never use:

  • stock humans
  • cliché AI visuals
  • bright neon tech imagery

docs.title: 10.1.4 Interaction
docs.text:
Website motion should follow the Brando Motion System:

  • fade-up text
  • slow diagram shifts
  • light node pulses
  • subtle edge animations
  • no scrolling gimmicks
  • no bouncing or parallax overload

docs.title: 10.2 Product UI Application (App, Dashboard & Semantic Editor)
docs.text: Brando’s product experiences must embody semantic structure. The UI must feel like a policy graph brought to life.

docs.title: 1. Clarity first
docs.text: No heavy chrome, no clutter.

docs.title: 2. Data > decoration
docs.text: Everything is functional and readable.

docs.title: 3. Neutral base
docs.text: UI uses Slate, Cloud, and White — never aurora colors as backgrounds.

docs.title: 4. Semantic emphasis
docs.text: Nodes, edges, contexts, policies appear visually meaningful.

docs.title: 5. Consistency
docs.text: Every component follows the spacing, grid, and iconography rules.

docs.title: 10.2.2 Semantic Graph UI (Signature Component)
docs.text: The Brand Policy Graph is the heart of the Brando product experience.

docs.title: Nodes
docs.text:
• Circular (8–12px radius)
  • Neutral or accent when active
  • Pulsing on interaction

docs.title: Edges
docs.text:
• Straight
  • 45° or 90°
  • Minimal thickness (1–2px)
  • Directional shimmer for active routes

docs.title: Labels
docs.text:
• Inter Body S
  • Neutral tones
  • Never visually heavy

docs.title: Hover Behavior
docs.text:
• Node enlarges +2px
  • Edge brightens

docs.title: Click Behavior
docs.text:
• Node locks into accent (cyan or green)
  • Connected nodes glow

The graph should feel alive but governed, not chaotic.

docs.title: Buttons
docs.text:
• Primary: charcoal
  • Secondary: outlined
  • Accent button: limited use for high-value actions

docs.title: Tabs
docs.text:
• Underline motion
  • Clean labels
  • No backgrounds

docs.title: Cards
docs.text:
• Minimal
  • Rounded 6px
  • Soft border only

docs.title: Panels
docs.text:
• 32–48px padding
  • Clear structure for settings and policy configuration

docs.title: Code Blocks
docs.text:
• Plex Mono
  • Faint background
  • Used for actual JSON-LD policy previews

docs.title: 10.2.4 Onboarding Screens
docs.text:
Use:

  • aurora gradient
  • semantic diagrams
  • minimal copy
  • strong narrative about control & governance

Tone:

  • calm
  • confident
  • intelligent

docs.title: 10.3 Documentation Application (Docs, API references, Spec Library)
docs.text: Documentation for Brando must reflect clarity and authority, mirroring the style of W3C, Schema.org, and API specs.

docs.title: 10.3.1 Layout
docs.text:
• Left sidebar navigation
  • Right content area
  • 8-column or 10-column text width
  • Abundant whitespace
  • No decorative imagery

docs.title: 10.3.2 Typography
docs.text:
• Body M (16px)
  • H2 and H3 for structure
  • Mono for anything machine-readable

docs.title: 10.3.3 Code Blocks
docs.text:
• Plex Mono
  • Indented
  • Structured
  • Faint line dividers
  • Highlighted key lines

Example:

{
  "@context": "https://brandoschema.com/",
  "@type": "Brand",
  "name": "Brando"
}

docs.title: 10.3.4 Diagrams
docs.text:
For explaining:

  • brand contexts
  • tokens
  • policies
  • category mapping
  • GTIN bindings

Use node + edge diagrams aligned to the grid.

docs.title: 10.3.5 Voice & Tone
docs.text:
Documentation tone:

  • factual
  • specific
  • non-salesy
  • technical
  • structured

Write like a standard, not like marketing.

docs.title: 10.4 Presentation Slides (Keynotes, Sales, Category Launch)
docs.text: Presentations must feel premium and cinematic.

docs.title: Title Slide
docs.text:
• Black or aurora gradient
  • Oversized Display headline
  • Semantic node pattern subtly in background

docs.title: Content Slides
docs.text:
• Large margins
  • 24–48px spacing
  • Minimal bullet points
  • Use H2 for section headers

docs.title: Diagrams
docs.text:
• Clean, white or black backgrounds
  • Nodes + edges as primary visuals

docs.title: 10.4.2 Motion in Slides
docs.text:
Subtle animations only:

  • fade-up text
  • slow diagram reveals
  • subtle aurora drift

Never:

  • wipe transitions
  • 3D flips
  • bounce-ins
  • cartoon motion

docs.title: 10.5 Social Media Application
docs.text: Brando uses a calm, premium tone even on social.

docs.title: Profile Icons
docs.text:
• Symbol-only
  • Charcoal or aurora gradient

docs.title: Posts
docs.text:
• semantic diagrams
  • short thought-leadership statements
  • code snippets
  • governance insights

docs.title: Do NOT use
docs.text:
• memes
  • emojis
  • stock photography of people

Brando speaks like a standard, not a personality-driven brand.

docs.title: 10.6 Print Application
docs.text:
Though rare, print moments exist for:

  • conferences
  • whitepapers
  • executive decks

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• high contrast
  • minimal color
  • clean typography
  • no heavy gradients
  • matte finishes over gloss

docs.title: 10.7 Brand Application Matrix
docs.text: Surface Personality Requirements Website premium + atmospheric aurora + structure Product UI controlled + semantic graph-centric Documentation technical + clear mono + grid Slides cinematic + minimal aurora + motion Social authoritative diagrams + code Print premium black & white + sharp type

docs.title: 10.8 Purpose of the Application System
docs.text:
Every application amplifies Brando’s identity:

  • The website introduces the category
  • The product makes the category real
  • The docs formalize the standard
  • The slides evangelize the standard
  • The social expresses thought leadership
  • The print embodies the premium nature

Together they show that Brando is not just a brand — it is the infrastructure of semantic governance for AI.

docs.title: CHAPTER 12 — BRAND ARCHITECTURE
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

Brando is not a simple product brand — it is a standard, a platform, and an emerging ecosystem. Chapter 12 defines how Brando’s brand architecture organizes:

  • The master brand
  • Sub-brands
  • Products and features
  • Extensions
  • Partner implementations
  • Category ownership

The key objective: Maintain a clear, authoritative system that scales while keeping Brando’s identity intact.

docs.title: 1. Master-Brand–Led
docs.text: Brando is the defining standard. All products and sub-brands inherit the master brand’s identity.

docs.title: 2. Semantic Hierarchy
docs.text:
Architecture reflects Brando’s worldview:

  • a core Brand node
  • connected sub-nodes
  • governed relationships
  • explicit meaning

docs.title: 3. Consistency Across Surfaces
docs.text: Naming, visuals, and behavior follow one unified system.

docs.title: 4. Flexibility Without Fragmentation
docs.text: New products may emerge, but must fit the architecture and naming rules.

docs.title: 5. Machine-Actionable Structuring
docs.text: The architecture is not only human-facing — it is designed to match BrandoSchema’s graph model.

docs.title: 12.2 The Brando Brand Graph (Conceptual Architecture)
docs.text: Brando’s brand architecture mirrors the conceptual shape of a semantic graph:

docs.title: Core Node:
docs.text: Brando — the standard, the policy graph, the identity authority.

docs.title: Primary Sub-Nodes:
docs.text: Represent major product pillars or brand entities.

docs.title: Secondary Sub-Nodes:
docs.text: Features, functions, modules.

docs.title: External Nodes:
docs.text: Partners, clients, integrators.

docs.title: Edges:
docs.text: Governance relationships (rules, policies, schemas).

docs.title: Master Brand Name:
docs.text: Brando

docs.title: Master Brand Positioning:
docs.text: The Policy Graph for AI.

docs.title: Master Brand Role:
docs.text:
Defines and owns:

  • semantic governance
  • BrandoSchema
  • brand policy standards
  • visual & behavioral identity
  • the global practice of machine-actionable brand governance

docs.title: Master Brand Promise:
docs.text: A brand that is understood is a brand that is protected.

docs.title: 12.4 Sub-Brands (Core System)
docs.text: Brando supports a set of potential sub-brands that extend its mission while keeping the master identity.

docs.title: 12.4.1 BrandoSchema
docs.text:
Role: The open standard — JSON-LD vocabulary and ontology. Audience: Engineers, data teams, AI model implementers. Identity:

  • technical
  • neutral
  • schema-first

Naming: BrandoSchema must always appear as one word.

docs.title: 12.4.2 BrandoWorks
docs.text:
(Optional) Role: The service and consulting arm that helps enterprises implement BrandoSchema correctly.

Audience: Enterprise brand teams, governance leaders.

Identity: More human, but still rigorous.

docs.title: 12.4.3 Brando Studio
docs.text:
(Future optional) Role: Visual design tool for creating branded datasets / policy graph visualizations.

Identity: Creative but controlled.

docs.title: 12.4.4 Brando Governance Cloud
docs.text:
(Future optional) Role: Enterprise platform for:

  • policy versioning
  • compliance tracking
  • campaign overrides
  • runtime governance
  • partner integrations

Identity: More product/UI-centric.

docs.title: 12.5 Feature-Level Entities (Secondary Brand Nodes)
docs.text:
Secondary nodes represent features, capabilities, or modules.

These MUST:

  • use Brando’s naming rules
  • not form independent brands
  • inherit Brando’s visual identity
  • not create visual fragmentation

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
• Brando Policy Engine
  • Brando Category Mapper
  • Brando Tone Modeler
  • Brando Context Builder
  • Brando Compliance Layer
  • Brando Campaign Overrides
  • Brando GTIN Binding Tool
  • Brando Governance API
  • Brando Semantic Dashboard

docs.title: Naming Rule:
docs.text:
Always structured as: Brando + Function

Never create standalone names like:

  • “Pulse”
  • “FlowEngine”
  • “BrandSync”

Brando is the standard — its name leads.

docs.title: 12.6 Partner Architecture
docs.text: Partners and integrators must maintain a subordinate visual identity when working with Brando.

docs.title: Allowed:
docs.text:
• “Powered by Brando”
  • “BrandoSchema Ready”
  • “Brando Integration Available”

docs.title: Not Allowed:
docs.text:
• Co-equal branding
  • Hybrid naming
  • Modifying Brando’s logo
  • Applying aurora gradients inside partner marks

docs.title: Partner Architecture Language:
docs.text:
“ integrates the Brando Policy Graph standard.”

Never: “ uses BrandoAI” or “ + Brando Platform.”

docs.title: 12.7 Category Ownership & Ecosystem Strategy
docs.text: Brando is building — and must own — a new category:

docs.title: Category Name:
docs.text: Brand Policy Graph

docs.title: Category Type:
docs.text: Semantic governance infrastructure for AI.

docs.title: Category Belongs To:
docs.text: Brando (Master Brand)

docs.title: Category Extensions:
docs.text:
Potential future expansions into:

  • branded agents
  • semantic compliance
  • data governance
  • AI model alignment
  • multi-brand orchestration

docs.title: Core Rule:
docs.text:
Never dilute category ownership by using inconsistent language.

Always refer to the category the same way: “Machine-Actionable Brand Policy Graph.”

docs.title: 12.8 Brand Naming Rules (For All Architecture Levels)
Rule 1 — Brando Always Leads
docs.text: Every product or module name must begin with “Brando”.

docs.title: Rule 2 — Names Are Descriptive, Not Metaphoric
docs.text: We describe what something is, not what it feels like.

docs.title: Rule 3 — No Acronyms
docs.text: Acronyms confuse both humans and machines.

docs.title: Rule 4 — No Cute or Playful Names
docs.text: Brando is a standard, not a SaaS startup.

docs.title: Rule 5 — Functions Use Technical Nouns
docs.text:
Examples:

  • Mapper
  • Engine
  • Builder
  • Editor
  • Layer
  • Registry
  • Connector
  • API

docs.title: Rule 6 — No Duplicate Brand Personalities
docs.text: All sub-brands inherit the master brand’s tone and visual language.

docs.title: 12.9 Brand Architecture Diagram
docs.text:
(Conceptual Graph View)

Brando (Master Brand)
 ├── BrandoSchema (Standard)
 │     ├── Policy Definitions
 │     ├── Context Vocabulary
 │     └── Category/GTIN Bindings
 ├── BrandoWorks (Implementation & Consulting)
 ├── Brando Governance Cloud (Enterprise Product)
 │     ├── Policy Engine
 │     ├── Category Mapper
 │     ├── Compliance Layer
 │     ├── Context Builder
 │     └── Campaign Overrides
 ├── Ecosystem Partners (Powered by Brando)
 └── Applied Brand Graphs (Enterprise Outputs)

This diagram reflects the semantic structure Brando is built on.

docs.title: 12.10 Future-Proof Architecture
docs.text: Brando’s architecture must be:

docs.title: Scalable
docs.text: Able to add new sub-brands or modules without breaking consistency.

docs.title: Semantic
docs.text: Aligned with BrandoSchema’s graph model and ontology.

docs.title: Stable
docs.text: Foundational categories (Brando, BrandoSchema) should never change.

docs.title: Global
docs.text:
Prepared for:

  • multiple languages
  • regional guidelines
  • different AI ecosystems

docs.title: Machine-Readable
docs.text: Meaningful for AI systems, not just humans.

docs.title: 12.11 Architecture Stewardship
docs.text: Maintaining the brand:

docs.title: Allowed:
docs.text:
• adding new modules that follow naming rules
  • expanding capabilities within existing sub-brands
  • creating new semantic families inside BrandoSchema

docs.title: Requires Approval:
docs.text:
• new sub-brands
  • changes to category definition
  • new brand narratives
  • major architectural shifts

docs.title: 12.12 Architecture Summary
docs.text:
Brando’s brand architecture is:

  • Master-brand–led
  • Semantic
  • Governed
  • Flexible but disciplined
  • Designed for AI interpretation
  • Built like a graph

It ensures that as Brando grows into a global standard, the brand grows in a structured, consistent, and intentional way.

docs.title: CHAPTER 1 — BRAND ESSENCE
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

Chapter 1 defines the core identity of Brando — the idea, promise, and strategic essence that informs everything else in the brand system.

docs.title: 1.1 Brand Purpose
docs.text:
To give brands a voice in the age of Generative AI — clear, consistent, and unbreakable.

Brando exists so AI systems can:

  • represent brands accurately
  • respect brand rules
  • protect brand identity
  • behave consistently across every model and channel

Traditional brand guidelines tell humans how to behave. Brando tells machines.

docs.title: 1.2 Brand Essence (The Core Idea)
docs.text:
Semantic Governance.

Brando is the semantic layer that defines how AI systems speak, design, and act on behalf of a brand.

The essence blends:

  • structured meaning
  • machine-actionable logic
  • brand identity
  • governance

This idea is new, distinct, and category-defining.

docs.title: 1.3 The Brand Idea in One Line
docs.text:
“The Policy Graph for AI.”

This line captures both:

  • The what: a portable policy graph
  • The why: to govern AI behavior

It positions Brando as the definitive standard for machine-actionable brand identity.

docs.title: 1.4 Brand Promise
docs.text:
A brand that is understood is a brand that is protected.

This is the functional and emotional promise of Brando. AI alignment is impossible without machine-readable identity.

Brando makes brand governance:

  • consistent
  • portable
  • enforceable
  • scalable

Across every AI system — everywhere the brand appears.

docs.title: 1.5 Brand Positioning
docs.text:
Brando is the first platform and standard for machine-actionable brand governance, enabling enterprises to control their identity across generative AI, agents, and automated systems.

It sits at the intersection of:

  • brand strategy
  • semantic data modeling
  • AI behavior control

This positioning is unmatched in the current market.

docs.title: 1.6 Brand Narrative (Macro Story)
docs.text:
Brands are losing control in the AI era: LLMs hallucinate tone, make claims, ignore compliance rules, misuse product information, and remix brand assets incorrectly.

The old model of brand guidelines — PDF documents for humans — cannot govern autonomous systems.

The insight: AI models already understand JSON-LD, and respond reliably to structured semantic context.

Brando turns brand identity, rules, tone, visual systems, and compliance policies into a machine-actionable policy graph that travels with the brand — portable across every model (OpenAI, Claude, Llama), every channel, every agent.

The result: For the first time, brands can govern AI behavior, not fix it afterwards.

This story defines Brando as:

  • a new category
  • a new standard
  • a new requirement for enterprise AI governance

docs.title: 1.7 Brand Characteristics
docs.text: Brando is:

docs.title: Authoritative
docs.text: We speak like the creator of a standard — not a startup.

docs.title: Minimal
docs.text: No fluff. No excess. Nothing unnecessary.

docs.title: Technical
docs.text: We embrace structure, data, precision, and formal semantics.

docs.title: Premium
docs.text: Everything feels intentional, elevated, sophisticated.

docs.title: Forward-thinking
docs.text: We are building the infrastructure for the next era of brand management.

docs.title: 1.8 Brand Personality Traits
docs.text: Trait Description Intelligent Always rooted in deep understanding of AI and semantics. Precise Every word, visual, and structure is intentional. Confident Clear, steady, authoritative — never loud. Minimalist Only what is essential. No decoration. Technical-Elegant Clean, modern, engineered with care. Pragmatic Focused, grounded, and actionable.

docs.title: 1.9 Brand Tone Summary
docs.text:
Brando’s tone blends:

  • clarity
  • structure
  • confidence
  • technical fluency
  • strategic calm

The tone reflects the nature of governance itself: firm, clear, reliable, and consistent.

docs.title: 1.10 Brand Architecture Statement
docs.text:
Brando is not a tool — it is a standard. Its architecture is built around:

  • a core identity (the Brand node)
  • semantic contexts
  • tokens
  • policies
  • campaigns
  • products
  • categories
  • GTIN bindings

This architecture is the foundation for machine-actionable brand governance.

docs.title: COLOR — BRAND GUIDELINES (CHAPTER 4)
docs.text: Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

docs.title: 4. Color System
docs.text:
Brando’s color system balances technical precision with the natural phenomenon of the Northern Lights. The palette is intentionally minimal in its core, with carefully controlled accents inspired by aurora gradients.

The goal is clarity first, with controlled energy where needed.

docs.title: 1. Clarity is the foundation
docs.text: Brando operates in a high-precision domain. Therefore, monochrome neutrals form the core palette.

docs.title: 2. Color is functional, not decorative
docs.text: Accents guide attention, signify hierarchy, and clarify interactions — not embellish.

docs.title: 3. Northern Lights as inspiration
docs.text:
The aurora colors express:

  • energy
  • intelligence
  • connected systems
  • nature’s geometry
  • dynamic movement

These qualities parallel the nature of semantic governance.

docs.title: 4. Gradients, not flat colors, represent transformation
docs.text: Auroras are gradients, not blocks. Brando uses gradients sparingly — for moments of emphasis, not as a default.

docs.title: 4.2 Core Neutral Palette (The Foundation)
docs.text:
These neutrals are the backbone of the brand — used in 80–90% of UI, typography, layout, and structural elements.

Name Hex Use Black / Charcoal #121212 Primary text, premium surfaces Graphite #1C1C1E Dark UI backgrounds Slate #2C2C2E Secondary dark backgrounds Steel Gray #6F6F6F Secondary text Cloud #E0E0E0 Dividers / strokes Snow #FAFAFA Light surfaces White #FFFFFF Primary light background

These tones keep Brando looking premium, professional, and timeless.

docs.title: 4.3 Aurora Accent Palette (The Signature)
docs.text:
Inspired by the Northern Lights — refined, not neon; atmospheric, not playful.

These colors are used sparingly for:

  • highlights
  • active states
  • callouts
  • diagrams
  • product UI signals
  • hero gradients

They give Brando its unique personality.

docs.title: Aurora Green
docs.text:
• Hex: #6FFFB0
  • Meaning: Clarity, intelligence, signal
  • Use: Positive indicators, highlights, interactive states

docs.title: Aurora Cyan
docs.text:
• Hex: #4FE5F8
  • Meaning: Connectivity, flow, precision
  • Use: Primary accent for UI, links, data lines

docs.title: Aurora Violet
docs.text:
• Hex: #8D68FF
  • Meaning: Creativity, depth, semantic layers
  • Use: Secondary accent, diagrams, highlights

docs.title: Aurora Magenta
docs.text:
• Hex: #DB4CFF
  • Meaning: Energy, transformation
  • Use: Rare accent, caution-highlighting, advanced features

docs.title: 4.4 The Brando Gradient (Hero Element)
docs.text:
A sophisticated, Northern Lights–inspired gradient for hero moments:

linear-gradient(
  135deg,
  #6FFFB0 0%,
  #4FE5F8 30%,
  #8D68FF 70%,
  #DB4CFF 100%
)

Usage:

  • Landing page hero
  • Major slides
  • Key visuals
  • Section dividers
  • Background behind policy graph illustrations

Rules:

  • NEVER use text on top without 90% opacity black/white overlay
  • NEVER apply to body copy
  • NEVER overuse
  • This is a brand “moment,” not a default

docs.title: Success (positive state)
docs.text: • #6FFFB0 (Aurora Green)

docs.title: Information
docs.text: • #4FE5F8 (Aurora Cyan)

docs.title: Warning
docs.text: • #F8D34F (Aurora Gold) ← subtle, not harsh

docs.title: Error
docs.text:
• #FF4F72 (Aurora Red) Inspired by the “red edge” often seen at the base of auroras.

Important: These are tinted, not flat hues — matching the atmospheric tone of the Northern Lights.

docs.title: 4.6 Accessibility Rules
docs.text:
• Body text must be #121212 on white / snow backgrounds
  • Headings must maintain 4.5:1 contrast
  • Aurora accents should never be used for large text
  • Avoid placing light aurora colors on white backgrounds
  • Tooltips, badges, and tags must use dark neutrals for text
  • Gradients must be accessibility-supported via overlays

docs.title: 4.7 Color Usage Ratios
docs.text:
Brando uses strict ratios to maintain visual discipline:

  • Neutral Palette: 80–90%
  • Aurora Accents (Flat): 8–12%
  • Aurora Gradient: 1–3%
  • Functional Colors: as needed (minimal)

We are a premium technical brand, not a colorful SaaS.

docs.title: ❌ Don’t use aurora colors for body text
❌ Don’t place cyan or green on white without outlining
❌ Don’t use gradients as section backgrounds everywhere
❌ Don’t use bright neon versions of aurora hues
❌ Don’t let color overshadow content or structure
docs.text: Brando’s presence must feel calm, technical, controlled.

docs.title: 4.9 CSS Token System (Brand Color Variables)
docs.text:
:root {
  /* Neutral Core */
  --color-black: #121212;
  --color-graphite: #1C1C1E;
  --color-slate: #2C2C2E;
  --color-gray: #6F6F6F;
  --color-cloud: #E0E0E0;
  --color-snow: #FAFAFA;
  --color-white: #FFFFFF;

  /* Aurora Accents */
  --aurora-green: #6FFFB0;
  --aurora-cyan: #4FE5F8;
  --aurora-violet: #8D68FF;
  --aurora-magenta: #DB4CFF;

  /* Gradient */
  --brando-gradient:
    linear-gradient(135deg, #6FFFB0, #4FE5F8, #8D68FF, #DB4CFF);

  /* Functional */
  --color-success: #6FFFB0;
  --color-info: #4FE5F8;
  --color-warning: #F8D34F;
  --color-error: #FF4F72;
}

docs.title: Hero Gradient Block
docs.text: A subtle aurora glow behind the headline.

docs.title: UI Accent
docs.text: Cyan underlines, data-line strokes, active states.

docs.title: Visual Graphs
docs.text: Nodes in violet, edges in cyan, highlight nodes in green.

docs.title: Callouts
docs.text: Light aurora overlays for emphasis.

docs.title: 4.11 Color in the Brand’s Story
docs.text:
Color supports Brando’s narrative:

  • Neutral palette → governance, control, clarity
  • Aurora accents → dynamic energy, machine interpretation, semantic flow
  • Gradient → transformation, alignment, structure emerging from noise

Brando’s color system is not aesthetic alone — it visually communicates the entire purpose of the brand.

docs.title: CHAPTER 14 — CONTENT GUIDELINES
docs.text:
Advanced Writing Standards for Brando Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

Brando’s content guidelines govern how the brand writes, ensuring every sentence—whether created by a human or an AI model—reflects Brando’s identity: precise, semantic, minimal, authoritative.

Content is not just communication. It is an extension of Brando’s governance system.

docs.title: 14.1 Content Philosophy
docs.text: Brando’s content must embody:

docs.title: Clarity
docs.text: Say exactly what is meant. Nothing more.

docs.title: Precision
docs.text: Use exact terms with explicit meaning. No synonyms.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text: Organize ideas like nodes in a semantic graph.

docs.title: Authority
docs.text: Speak like the custodian of a standard — calm, confident, declarative.

docs.title: Minimalism
docs.text: Remove everything unnecessary: words, sentences, adjectives.

docs.title: Machine Interpretability
docs.text:
Write in a way that both humans and LLMs can parse with clarity.

Content should feel governed, not expressive.

docs.title: 14.2 The Brando Content Model
docs.text: All Brando content follows a three-layer semantic hierarchy:

docs.title: 1. Conceptual Layer
docs.text: Defines what the idea is: semantic governance, policy graph, identity, context.

docs.title: 2. Explanatory Layer
docs.text: Describes what Brando does: creates a machine-actionable brand identity.

docs.title: 3. Operational Layer
docs.text:
Explains how Brando works: rules, contexts, schemas, policies, GTIN bindings.

The layers must appear in order—top to bottom—across all content formats.

docs.title: A. Clarity
docs.text:
• Plain, direct language
  • No long sentences
  • No decorative phrasing

docs.title: B. Authority
docs.text:
• Declarative statements
  • No hedging or uncertainty
  • No exaggerated claims

docs.title: C. Precision
docs.text:
• Use technical nouns
  • Use Brando’s canonical vocabulary
  • Avoid synonyms

docs.title: D. Minimalism
docs.text:
• Short paragraphs
  • Limited adjectives
  • Tight, clean phrasing

docs.title: E. Calmness
docs.text:
• No hype
  • No exclamation marks
  • No emotional tone

docs.title: 14.4 Writing Rules
docs.text: These rules apply equally to humans and AI.

docs.title: Rule 1 — One Idea per Sentence
docs.text:
Avoid multi-clause sentences or winding logic.

Correct:

AI cannot infer your brand. Brando provides the semantic policy graph. Models follow it consistently.

docs.title: Rule 2 — Write in Crisp, Declarative Statements
docs.text: No flourishes, metaphors, or narrative filler.

docs.title: Rule 3 — Remove All Fluff Words
docs.text:
Forbidden words:

  • innovative
  • magical
  • powerful
  • future-proof
  • next-gen
  • game-changing
  • unleashed

These weaken the brand.

docs.title: Rule 4 — Use Policy-Like Language
docs.text:
Write like you are defining a standard, not selling a product.

Example:

Policies must be evaluated before generation. Tone must comply with defined contexts. Claims must remain within regulatory boundaries.

docs.title: Rule 5 — Use Canonical Brando Vocabulary Only
docs.text:
Appropriate terms:

  • semantic
  • governance
  • brand identity
  • context
  • policy graph
  • machine-actionable
  • precision
  • schema
  • GTIN
  • consistency
  • override
  • binding
  • lineage

Avoid synonyms or invented terms.

docs.title: Rule 6 — Structure Content Like a Semantic Graph
docs.text:
Use clear:

  • nodes (ideas)
  • edges (relationships)
  • hierarchies (sections)

This reflects Brando’s worldview.

docs.title: Rule 7 — Short Paragraphs Only
docs.text: 1–3 sentences each.

docs.title: Rule 8 — No Emotional or Friendly Tone
docs.text:
Brando is not conversational.

Forbidden:

  • humor
  • emojis
  • friendly marketing voice

docs.title: Rule 9 — Use Parallel Structure
docs.text:
For lists or sequences, maintain consistent form.

Example:

One standard. One graph. Every model. Consistent behavior.

docs.title: Rule 10 — Sound Like a Standard
docs.text:
Content must have the tone of:

  • W3C
  • Schema.org
  • GS1
  • ISO

Authoritative, structured, minimal.

docs.title: A. Website Copy
docs.text:
• Category → value → product
  • Declarative statements
  • 50–75 words per block
  • No friendly tone

docs.title: B. Product UI Copy
docs.text:
• Extremely short
  • Technical nouns (Engine, Mapper, Context, Override)
  • No marketing language
  • No “you” or conversational phrasing

docs.title: C. Documentation
docs.text:
• Reference tone
  • Technical accuracy
  • JSON-LD examples often
  • No persuasion

docs.title: D. Presentations
docs.text:
• One idea per slide
  • Minimal bullets
  • Large, declarative lines

docs.title: E. Press / Thought Leadership
docs.text:
• Own the category
  • Keep emotional language out
  • Use semantic framing

docs.title: F. Social
docs.text:
• Direct, minimal statements
  • No emojis
  • No hype
  • Semantic insights only

docs.title: Core Lexicon
docs.text:
• semantic
  • governance
  • policy graph
  • identity
  • context
  • consistency
  • precision
  • rule
  • machine-actionable
  • JSON-LD
  • schema
  • token
  • category
  • GTIN
  • override
  • lineage
  • binding
  • brand node

docs.title: Forbidden Lexicon
docs.text:
• innovative
  • magical
  • unleash
  • reimagine
  • disruptive
  • supercharge
  • game-changing
  • elevate
  • empower

docs.title: 14.7 Sentence Patterns
docs.text: Brando uses the following templates consistently:

docs.title: Pattern 1: Governance Statement
docs.text: The model must load the Brand Policy Graph before generating content.

docs.title: Pattern 2: Semantic Fact
docs.text: A brand must be machine-readable to remain consistent across models.

docs.title: Pattern 3: Problem → Semantic Truth → Resolution
docs.text: AI guesses. Guessing is not governance. Brando provides the policy graph.

docs.title: Pattern 4: Parallelism
docs.text: One standard. One graph. Every model. Consistent behavior.

docs.title: Pattern 5: Technical Explanation
docs.text: Policies define allowed and disallowed outputs. Contexts encode tone and regional variation. Tokens define reusable expressions.

docs.title: Pattern 6: Instructional Language
docs.text: Use the brand node as the canonical identity. Attach contexts to specify behavior. Encode policies to enforce compliance.

docs.title: 14.8 AI Writing Rules (For LLMs)
docs.text: AI writing for Brando must follow strict constraints:

docs.title: Must
docs.text:
• Load Brando tone and vocabulary
  • Use declarative sentences
  • Follow narrative hierarchy
  • Apply Brando’s Integrity Audit
  • Preserve canonical terminology
  • Keep output minimal and structured

docs.title: Must Not
docs.text:
• Invent new terms
  • Use synonyms for core concepts
  • Become conversational
  • Add hype or emotion
  • Produce long paragraphs

docs.title: 14.9 The Brando Integrity Audit (Self-Check for Writers & AI)
docs.text: Before publishing, content must meet all five criteria:

docs.title: 1. Clarity Audit
docs.text: Is every sentence simple and direct?

docs.title: 2. Semantic Audit
docs.text: Is vocabulary canonical and precise?

docs.title: 3. Narrative Audit
docs.text: Does it follow category → value → product hierarchy?

docs.title: 4. Tone Audit
docs.text: Is the voice calm, authoritative, minimal?

docs.title: 5. Governance Audit
docs.text:
Does it read like a standard?

If not: revise.

docs.title: 14.10 Prompt Governance Principles
docs.text:
(New Section)

Prompts are part of Brando’s governance. They must enforce:

docs.title: 1. Identity Loading
docs.text: Start every prompt with Brando’s tonal constraints.

docs.title: 2. Declarative Instructions
docs.text: Use explicit, unambiguous rules.

docs.title: 3. Canonical Vocabulary
docs.text: Require Brando’s lexicon only.

docs.title: 4. Structural Expectations
docs.text:
Instruct models to use:

  • short sentences
  • semantic narrative flow
  • lists when needed

docs.title: 5. No Invented Terms
docs.text: Prompt must forbid synonyms.

docs.title: 6. Minimalism
docs.text: No fluff. No verbosity.

docs.title: 7. Governance Tone
docs.text: Require standard-like language.

docs.title: 8. Semantic Structure
docs.text: Require outputs follow the narrative pyramid.

docs.title: 9. Bind to BrandoSchema
docs.text: For JSON-LD and structured outputs.

docs.title: 10. Self-Audit
docs.text: Require the model to apply Brando’s Integrity Audit.

docs.title: 11. Modular Prompts
docs.text: Prompts should be reusable components.

docs.title: 12. No Creative Verbs
docs.text: Avoid “imagine,” “explore,” “brainstorm.”

docs.title: 13. Model-Agnostic Design
docs.text:
Prompts must work across OpenAI, Claude, Gemini, Llama.

Prompts = machine-facing brand governance.

docs.title: 14.11 Chapter Summary
docs.text:
Brando content must always be:

  • precise
  • minimal
  • semantic
  • structured
  • authoritative
  • consistent
  • governed

This chapter defines the rules that ensure the Brando voice remains coherent across:

  • web
  • product
  • docs
  • slides
  • social
  • AI systems

Content is part of the standard. Writing is governance.

docs.title: CHAPTER 11 — GOVERNANCE & BRAND STEWARDSHIP
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

Brando is not just a visual identity — it is a semantic governance standard. Therefore, the brand itself must be governed with the same clarity, precision, and discipline that it enables for enterprise clients.

This chapter defines how Brando must be managed, protected, applied, and extended across internal teams, partners, agencies, and AI systems.

docs.title: 11.1 Brand Stewardship Philosophy
docs.text: Brando’s brand stewardship is built on four principles:

docs.title: 1. Consistency
docs.text: A standard is only a standard if it is followed rigorously. Everything must align to the identity system.

docs.title: 2. Clarity
docs.text: Use the brand guidelines to remove ambiguity, not create flexibility. Clarity = strength.

docs.title: 3. Precision
docs.text: Every use must be intentional — typography, spacing, color, motion, policy structure.

docs.title: 4. Governance First
docs.text:
Brando is the governance layer for enterprises. Its own brand must demonstrate governance through its behavior, not just its messaging.

This chapter formalizes the rules and responsibilities.

docs.title: 11.2 Brand Governance Model
docs.text: Brando uses a three-tier stewardship model:

docs.title: Tier 1 — Core Brand Team (Custodians of the Standard)
docs.text:
Responsible for:

  • Maintaining the Brando identity
  • Updating guidelines
  • Approving major assets
  • Defining new visual tokens
  • Managing BrandoSchema evolutions
  • Protecting semantic and visual integrity

The Core Brand Team has ultimate authority over the brand.

docs.title: Tier 2 — Authorized Contributors
docs.text:
Includes:

  • Designers
  • Writers
  • Engineers
  • Agency partners
  • Product teams

Responsibilities:

  • Follow all brand rules
  • Use approved components
  • Request approval for new patterns
  • Maintain semantic consistency across all outputs

They may propose, but may not publish without approval.

docs.title: Tier 3 — External Implementers
docs.text:
Includes:

  • Clients
  • Partners
  • Developers integrating BrandoSchema
  • AI model implementers
  • Platform hosts

Responsibilities:

  • Use Brando assets as provided
  • Maintain attribution where required
  • Do not modify or recreate the Brando identity
  • Adhere to policy usage requirements

They may deploy, but not change or extend the brand.

docs.title: What Requires Approval
docs.text:
• Any new logo variation
  • Any new color variant
  • Any new icon category
  • Any new visual token
  • Changes to messaging / positioning
  • Use of Brando mark in partner campaigns
  • Any motion system variant
  • Any new product UI pattern not defined in Chapter 8

docs.title: What Does NOT Require Approval
docs.text:
• Use of standard components
  • Standard diagrams
  • Content blocks inside defined layout patterns
  • Application of provided templates

docs.title: Rule 1 — Never Add Personality “Fluff”
docs.text: Brando is not playful. Do not use emojis, jokes, over-friendliness, or pop tone.

docs.title: Rule 2 — Never Deviate from Grid Structure
docs.text: Everything must align to the system grid.

docs.title: Rule 3 — Never Use Unapproved Colors or Gradients
docs.text: Aurora colors are strictly defined. No improvisation.

docs.title: Rule 4 — Never Use Illustrations with Human Characters
docs.text: Brando is about semantic structure, not people.

docs.title: Rule 5 — Motion Must Fit the Brand System
docs.text: No bounces, spins, or elastic animations.

docs.title: Rule 6 — Always Use IBM Plex Mono for Code
docs.text: Never use Inter or any other font for JSON-LD.

docs.title: Rule 7 — Messaging Must Be Precise
docs.text: No vague claims. No exaggerated marketing language.

docs.title: 11.5 AI-Specific Brand Governance
docs.text: Because Brando is used inside AI models, brand stewardship includes machine-facing rules.

docs.title: AI Application Rules
docs.text:
• Always load the Brand Policy Graph before prompting
  • Do not override BrandoSchema logic
  • Do not invent new properties
  • Do not generate alternate naming conventions
  • Do not paraphrase governance rules
  • Always include required context nodes
  • Use the canonical Brando vocabulary

docs.title: When Brando Appears Inside Other AI:
docs.text:
• The brand voice must remain precise
  • LLMs must not invent visual identity elements
  • LLMs must follow exact policy structures
  • No hallucinated brand capabilities

docs.title: 11.6 Brand Policy for Partners & Integrators
docs.text: For partners integrating Brando into platforms:

docs.title: Must Include
docs.text:
• Brando attribution
  • Reference to BrandoSchema standard
  • Clear demarcation between platform logic and Brando logic

docs.title: May NOT Include
docs.text:
• Co-branded logo lockups without approval
  • Modified aurora color sets
  • Rewritten governance rules
  • Improvised schema classes or properties

docs.title: 11.7 Compliance Requirements
docs.text: Every asset, whether human-created or AI-generated, must pass:

docs.title: (1) The Structural Audit
docs.text:
Does it follow:

  • spacing system
  • typography hierarchy
  • grid alignment
  • color rules
  • motion primitives

docs.title: (2) The Semantic Audit
docs.text:
Does it:

  • align to governance messaging
  • express clarity and precision
  • avoid human-centric clichés
  • embody the semantic worldview

docs.title: (3) The Integrity Audit
docs.text:
Does it violate any:

  • don’ts
  • restricted usage
  • unapproved patterns

Everything must pass all three audits before publication.

docs.title: Every new designer must learn:
docs.text:
• grid & spacing
  • typography
  • semantic node diagrams
  • motion system
  • iconography rules

docs.title: Every new engineer must learn:
docs.text:
• CSS tokens
  • code block formatting
  • JSON-LD conventions
  • BrandoSchema relationships

docs.title: Every new writer must learn:
docs.text:
• tone consistency
  • semantic-first phrasing
  • precision rules
  • messaging pillars

Onboarding is mandatory.

docs.title: 11.9 Extensions & Future-Proofing
docs.text:
Brando is a standard — not a static identity.

Extensions may include:

  • new visual tokens
  • expanded aurora gradients
  • new diagrammatic primitives
  • expanded UI components
  • additional semantic categories
  • multi-language brand applications
  • new AI model guidelines

All extensions must follow:

  • the established grid
  • core color philosophy
  • brand structure
  • semantic tone
  • rule-based governance

docs.title: 11.10 Brand Stewardship Summary
docs.text:
Brando’s identity must always express:

  • stability
  • semantic clarity
  • governance
  • premium minimalism
  • structured intelligence

Brand stewardship ensures Brando remains:

  • coherent
  • authoritative
  • distinct
  • trustworthy
  • consistent across all surfaces

Brando is a standard — and a standard must be preserved.

docs.title: CHAPTER 8 — ICONOGRAPHY & COMPONENT SYSTEM
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

Brando’s iconography and UI components extend the brand’s philosophy of precision, structure, and semantic clarity. Icons and components should feel like visual tokens of a system — not decorative illustrations.

This chapter defines how icons, UI elements, and visual components express Brando’s identity across product, marketing, and documentation.

docs.title: 8.1 Iconography Philosophy
docs.text: Brando’s icons and components must reflect:

docs.title: 1. Semantic structure
docs.text: Icons behave like simplified nodes in a graph.

docs.title: 2. Precision
docs.text: Every line, corner, and angle is intentional.

docs.title: 3. Minimalism
docs.text: No unnecessary shapes, colors, or illustrative flair.

docs.title: 4. Technical calmness
docs.text: Icons are neutral by default; accents are used sparingly.

docs.title: 5. System-first behavior
docs.text: Icons must function cohesively as part of a larger design system, not as standalone art pieces.

docs.title: 8.2 Icon Style Overview
docs.text: Brando uses a line-based geometric icon style, influenced by UI system icons but modified for semantic clarity.

docs.title: Key Characteristics
docs.text:
• 1.5–2px stroke weight
  • Rounded joins kept to a minimum
  • Mostly 90° and 45° angles
  • Balanced negative space
  • Simplified shapes
  • Clear geometry
  • Neutral color by default (#121212)

Icons should feel:

  • modern
  • structured
  • calm
  • authoritative

Not playful or cartoonish.

docs.title: 8.3 Icon Grid & Construction
docs.text: All icons use a 24×24 pixel grid system.

docs.title: Construction Rules
docs.text:
• Stroke weight: 1.5px (UI), 2px (marketing)
  • Safe zone padding: 2px
  • Key shapes align to pixel grid
  • No half-pixel positioning
  • Curves are minimal — used only when essential
  • Icons must remain readable at 16px size

This ensures consistency and crisp rendering across devices and resolutions.

docs.title: Default Color:
docs.text:
• #121212 (light mode)
  • #FFFFFF (dark mode)

docs.title: Aurora Accents (limited use):
docs.text:
• Aurora Cyan (#4FE5F8)
  • Aurora Green (#6FFFB0)
  • Aurora Violet (#8D68FF)

Accent Color Rules:

  • Use sparingly
  • Only for active states, highlights, semantic cues
  • Never use more than one aurora color in the same icon

docs.title: 8.5 Icon Categories
docs.text: Brando’s icon system is grouped into functional categories:

docs.title: A. Navigation Icons
docs.text:
• Home
  • Dashboard
  • Documentation
  • Settings
  • Policies
  • Products
  • Insights
  • Help

docs.title: B. Action Icons
docs.text:
• Add / Create
  • Edit
  • Delete
  • Filter
  • Search
  • Upload
  • Download
  • Refresh
  • Save

docs.title: C. Semantic Graph Icons
docs.text:
(Unique to Brando)

  • Node
  • Edge
  • Graph cluster
  • Policy object
  • Category node
  • GTIN token
  • Override indicator
  • Context marker

docs.title: D. State Icons
docs.text:
• Success (green)
  • Info (cyan)
  • Warning (gold)
  • Error (aurora red)

docs.title: E. File & Data Icons
docs.text:
• JSON
  • CSV
  • Schema
  • Document
  • Media
  • Zip

docs.title: F. AI Behavior Icons
docs.text:
• Guardrail
  • Action
  • Automation
  • LLM
  • Agent
  • Model

These are Brando’s unique semantic visual vocabulary.

docs.title: 8.6 The “Semantic Node” Icon (Brando’s Signature)
docs.text: This is the most important icon in the system.

docs.title: Definition
docs.text:
A small geometric circle representing:

  • entities
  • brands
  • rules
  • context objects
  • nodes in a graph

docs.title: Variants
docs.text:
• Filled
  • Outlined
  • Connected
  • Highlighted (accent color)
  • Pulsed (animated)

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Never stretch or distort
  • Keep stroke proportion exact
  • Always grid-aligned
  • Use consistent spacing between nodes

This icon is a core part of Brando’s design DNA.

docs.title: 8.7 Component System Overview
docs.text:
Brando’s components reflect the same principles of:

  • clarity
  • structure
  • precision
  • minimalism

Components are never decorative — they are functional and semantic.

docs.title: Primary Button
docs.text:
• Background: #121212
  • Text: #FFFFFF
  • Radius: 4px
  • Padding: 12px 20px
  • Hover: slightly lighter charcoal
  • Active: cyan underline (1px)

docs.title: Secondary Button
docs.text:
• Border: 1px solid #121212
  • Text: #121212
  • Background: transparent
  • Hover: charcoal tint

docs.title: Accent Button (Limited Use)
docs.text:
• Background: #4FE5F8 (Aurora Cyan)
  • Text: black
  • Use only for high-value CTAs

docs.title: 8.7.2 Tabs
docs.text:
• Line-based, minimal
  • Active tab uses Aurora Cyan underline
  • Inactive tabs use Cloud (#E0E0E0)

docs.title: 8.7.3 Cards
docs.text:
• Neutral backgrounds (#FFFFFF or #FAFAFA)
  • Subtle shadow or border
  • 24px padding
  • Rounded corners: 6px
  • Never use bright gradients inside cards
  • Clean separation between header and content

docs.title: 8.7.4 Tables
docs.text:
• Minimal gridlines
  • Header row: graphite text
  • Body rows: slate text
  • Hover state: faint (#FAFAFA)
  • Code cells: IBM Plex Mono

docs.title: 8.7.5 Code Blocks
docs.text:
• Background: #F7F7F7
  • Border: #E0E0E0
  • Font: IBM Plex Mono
  • Padding: 16px
  • Optional aurora-highlighted lines

(Important for semantic examples & JSON-LD.)

docs.title: 8.7.6 Panels
docs.text:
Used for:

  • settings

  • policy configuration

  • graph visualization controls

  • documentation sections

  • Neutral background

  • 32–48px padding

  • Clear hierarchy

  • Subtle section dividers

docs.title: 8.8 Motion Tokens for Components
docs.text: Brando’s micro-interactions match the brand’s “quiet authority.”

docs.title: Buttons
docs.text:
• 120–160ms transitions
  • No bounce, no elasticity

docs.title: Tabs
docs.text: • Underline slides smoothly from left to right

docs.title: Nodes
docs.text:
• Subtle pulse
  • Glow transitions under 1 second

docs.title: Edges
docs.text:
• Shimmer traveling in one direction
  • Never looped animations

docs.title: Modals
docs.text:
• Fade in, fade out
  • No scaling

Motion should feel measured and controlled.

docs.title: ✔ DO
docs.text:
• Use icons sparingly
  • Keep stroke weights consistent
  • Use monocline geometry
  • Align icons perfectly to typographic grid
  • Use accent colors for semantic meaning
  • Maintain 8px spacing increments

docs.title: ✖ DON’T
docs.text:
• Use filled, cartoon, or playful icons
  • Mix stroke styles
  • Apply heavy shadows
  • Use multiple aurora accents together
  • Over-illustrate components
  • Add unnecessary flourish or curvature

docs.title: 8.10 How Icons Support Brando’s Identity
docs.text:
Icons visualize the same ideas that define the brand:

  • semantic nodes
  • governance rules
  • machine-readable structure
  • aurora energy for activated states

The icon system is a visual extension of the Brand Policy Graph itself.

docs.title: IMAGERY & ART DIRECTION — BRAND GUIDELINES (CHAPTER 6)
docs.text: Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

docs.title: 6. Imagery & Art Direction
docs.text:
Brando’s imagery reflects the essence of semantic structure, governed systems, and the natural intelligence of the Northern Lights. The visual universe must feel:

  • intentional
  • technical
  • atmospheric
  • minimal
  • premium
  • structured yet fluid

This chapter defines how Brando uses photography, abstract visuals, diagrams, and aurora-inspired imagery to create a distinctive and ownable visual world.

docs.title: 6.1 Art Direction Philosophy
docs.text: Brando’s imagery sits at the intersection of:

docs.title: (1) Natural energy
docs.text: The aurora: flow, motion, transformation.

docs.title: (2) Machine structure
docs.text: Nodes, edges, grids, semantics.

docs.title: (3) Governance
docs.text:
Clarity, balance, rules, consistency.

The art direction must always visually reinforce these fundamental ideas.

docs.title: 6.2 Core Imagery Themes
docs.text: Brando uses four primary imagery families:

docs.title: 1. Aurora Atmospherics (Signature)
docs.text:
Soft, glowing, Northern Lights–inspired visuals.

Used to convey:

  • energy
  • transformation
  • semantic flow
  • the “alive but contained” quality of intelligent systems

Colors are drawn directly from the Aurora palette:

  • greens
  • cyans
  • violets
  • magentas

Gradients are smooth, cinematic, and restrained.

docs.title: 2. Semantic Graphs (Structural)
docs.text:
Nodes and edges forming meaningful patterns.

Used to convey:

  • logic
  • data structure
  • policy relationships
  • AI interpretability

These illustrations can be:

  • fully abstract
  • representational
  • or directly based on a Brand Policy Graph

Always clean, minimal, and spatial.
