docs.title: 3. Abstract Architecture (Foundational)
docs.text:
Modern, geometric, high-contrast architectural images that evoke:

  • stability
  • precision
  • scale
  • structure

Examples include:

  • concrete forms
  • glass reflections
  • repeating geometric patterns
  • engineered materials

These images provide grounding and contrast to aurora softness.

docs.title: 4. Technical Close-Ups (Detail)
docs.text:
Macro views of:

  • circuit boards
  • connections
  • fibers
  • modular systems
  • technical surfaces

Used sparingly to reinforce the machine-actionable nature of Brando.

docs.title: 6.3 What Brando Imagery Should Feel Like
docs.text: A Brando image should feel:

docs.title: Quietly powerful
docs.text: Nothing loud, chaotic, or overly saturated.

docs.title: Intentional
docs.text: Every line, gradient, or shape has purpose.

docs.title: Balanced
docs.text: Aurora energy meets structured geometry.

docs.title: Dimensional
docs.text: Depth, not clutter. Space, not emptiness.

docs.title: Clean
docs.text: Minimal composition, high clarity, no visual noise.

docs.title: Premium
docs.text: This is not “tech startup playful.” This is enterprise governance.

docs.title: Aurora Images
docs.text:
• Use cyan, green, violet, magenta
  • Keep saturation moderate
  • Prioritize smooth transitions
  • Avoid neon or artificial “gaming” colors

docs.title: Black & White Architecture
docs.text:
• Deep contrast
  • Light grain allowed
  • No warm tones
  • High structural clarity

docs.title: Color Harmony
docs.text:
In a single layout, use only one of the following:

  • aurora image
  • architecture image
  • technical macro

Never blend multiple image families in one composition.

docs.title: 1. Negative space
docs.text: Imagery should never overwhelm typography or strategy diagrams.

docs.title: 2. Structural alignment
docs.text:
Place focal elements on:

  • thirds
  • center
  • or aligned to grid columns

docs.title: 3. Depth layering
docs.text: Use soft gradients or blur behind structural elements to create subtle atmospheric depth.

docs.title: 4. Directionality
docs.text:
Aurora flows should move:

  • upward
  • diagonally (30°–45°)
  • or left-to-right

Never downward — Brando is about forward motion and elevation.

docs.title: ✔ DO
docs.text:
• Use minimal, architectural photography
  • Prioritize geometric lines and negative space
  • Use atmospheric aurora shots for hero moments
  • Include close-up technological textures sparingly
  • Use cold, neutral color grading

docs.title: ✖ DON’T
docs.text:
• Use stock photos of people
  • Use corporate meeting-room photography
  • Use warm, saturated sunsets
  • Use nature scenes that aren’t aurora-related
  • Use illustrations that feel cartoonish or playful

Brando is not human-centric; it is brand-semantic-centric.

docs.title: 6.7 Diagram & Illustration Style
docs.text: Brando diagrams follow semantic graph logic:

docs.title: Nodes
docs.text:
• circular
  • clean outlines
  • neutral or aurora accent

docs.title: Edges
docs.text:
• 1–2px straight lines
  • no curvature
  • 45° or 90° angles only
  • minimal branching

docs.title: Labels
docs.text:
• Inter in small caps / body S
  • minimal text

docs.title: Grid
docs.text: Use a 12-column or 8-column underlying grid. Nodes may snap to grid intersections.

docs.title: Motion (if animated)
docs.text:
• slow
  • directional
  • data-like
  • not playful

docs.title: 6.8 Hero Visual System
docs.text:
Hero visuals combine:

  • aurora gradients
  • semantic nodes & edges
  • dimensional depth
  • subtle shadow or glow
  • structural composition

This is Brando’s most iconic expression.

Key rules:

  • Typography always sits on stable, high-contrast areas
  • Never place text directly over a bright aurora area
  • Apply subtle overlays for readability
  • Movement must be minimal and atmospheric

docs.title: For Aurora Imagery:
docs.text:
• Apply subtle vignette for focus
  • Optional grain for cinematic texture
  • Keep blur radius soft

docs.title: For Architecture:
docs.text:
• Convert to monochrome
  • Apply clarity and contrast
  • Keep surfaces clean
  • Avoid recognizable landmarks

docs.title: For Technical Close-Ups:
docs.text:
• Metallic tones
  • High detail
  • Cool color temperature

docs.title: ❌ Warm color environments (orange, yellow, red tones)
❌ Stock “AI brain,” glowing circuits, wireframe heads
❌ Overlapping multiple imagery families in a single layout
docs.text: Brando must always feel modern, intentional, and premium.

docs.title: Hero Section Example
docs.text: A soft aurora gradient with a single semantic graph node pattern lightly behind the headline.

docs.title: Documentation Example
docs.text: Neutral background + minimal diagram showing policy graph structure.

docs.title: Product UI Example
docs.text: Small semantic nodes marking active states; otherwise grayscale UI.

docs.title: Marketing Slide Example
docs.text: Split screen: black & white geometry on left, aurora ribbon on right.

docs.title: 6.12 How Imagery Supports Brando’s Brand Narrative
docs.text:
Imagery isn’t decoration — it is part of meaning.

It communicates:

  • Governance (structure, architecture)
  • Semantic flow (aurora gradients)
  • AI interpretability (technical close-ups)
  • Brand identity (node diagrams)

Brando imagery should feel like the visual language of a new standard — the way HTML once felt for browsers.

docs.title: CHAPTER 17 — IMPLEMENTATION PLAYBOOKS
docs.text:
Execution Standards for Web, Product, Documentation & AI Systems Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

The Implementation Playbooks provide practical, step-by-step instructions for deploying Brando’s brand system consistently across Web, Product UI, Documentation, and AI environments.

Each playbook translates the identity system into repeatable processes that ensure precision, semantic alignment, and governed behavior everywhere Brando appears.

Brando is a standard — and implementation must be standardized.

docs.title: 17.1 Playbook Philosophy
docs.text: Every implementation must follow four principles:

docs.title: 1. Semantic Fidelity
docs.text: Everything matches the underlying BrandoSchema model.

docs.title: 2. Visual Consistency
docs.text: Typography, color, spacing, and iconography must follow the system exactly.

docs.title: 3. System Integrity
docs.text: Components, diagrams, and tokens are used as defined — no variations.

docs.title: 4. Platform-Specific Adaptation
docs.text: Rules flex only where the platform requires it, not for creative expression.

docs.title: 17.2 Web Implementation Playbook
docs.text:
(For brandoworks.com, landing pages, microsites, campaigns)

This playbook ensures Brando’s web presence reflects the brand standard with precision and semantic clarity.

docs.title: 17.2.1 Layout & Grid
docs.text:
Mandatory:

  • 12-column grid
  • 72px vertical section spacing
  • Max content width: 1280px
  • Hero padding: 96px +

Never:

  • Break the grid
  • Collapse margins
  • Center large blocks of body text

docs.title: 17.2.2 Typography Rules
docs.text:
• Use Inter for all UI and marketing copy
  • Use IBM Plex Mono for code, JSON-LD, and technical labels
  • Use the modular type scale exactly
  • Never mix unrelated font sizes

Hero text max width: 680px

docs.title: 17.2.3 Color Application
docs.text:
• Neutrals: 80–90%
  • Aurora accents: 8–12%
  • Gradients: 1–3%, hero sections only
  • Never use aurora colors as large backgrounds
  • Never combine multiple aurora colors in one element

docs.title: 17.2.4 Imagery Rules
docs.text:
Allowed:

  • aurora atmospherics
  • architectural photography
  • semantic diagrams

Not allowed:

  • stock people
  • “AI brain” clip-art
  • cliché tech imagery

docs.title: 17.2.5 Components
docs.text:
Use only components defined in Chapter 8:

  • buttons
  • cards
  • tabs
  • panels
  • diagram blocks
  • code blocks

No improvisation. No modified radii, shadows, or spacing.

docs.title: 17.2.6 Interaction & Motion
docs.text:
• Fade-up for text
  • Slow node pulsing
  • Edge shimmer directional only
  • No parallax gimmicks
  • No bouncy or playful animation

docs.title: 17.2.7 Web Integrity Audit
docs.text:
Before publishing:

  • Check architecture (structure)
  • Check semantic alignment (copy)
  • Check visuals (identity compliance)
  • Check performance (asset optimization)

docs.title: 17.3 Product UI Implementation Playbook
docs.text:
(For the Brando Platform / Governance Cloud / Tools)

Product UI must feel like a live expression of the Brand Policy Graph.

docs.title: 17.3.1 Grid & Structure
docs.text:
• Use the 8-column UI grid
  • 20px gutters
  • 40px margins
  • Strong, consistent whitespace

docs.title: 17.3.2 Typography in Product
docs.text:
• Inter 14–16px primary
  • Plex Mono for all identifiers
  • No bold unless structural
  • No all-caps

docs.title: 17.3.3 Component Rules
docs.text: UI components must match Chapter 8 exactly.

docs.title: Buttons
docs.text:
• Charcoal primary
  • Cyan active
  • Minimal radius

docs.title: Tabs
docs.text:
• Line-based only
  • Cyan indicator

docs.title: Tables
docs.text:
• Minimal lines
  • Clean cells
  • No zebra striping

docs.title: Cards & Panels
docs.text:
• Soft borders
  • No heavy shadows

docs.title: 17.3.4 Semantic Graph Rendering Rules
docs.text:
Nodes:

  • 8–12px
  • Perfect circles
  • Neutrals
  • Cyan/green highlight states

Edges:

  • Straight
  • 1–2px
  • 45° or 90° only

Labels:

  • Inter Body S
  • Single-line only

Graph must appear:

  • governed
  • logical
  • systematic
  • never chaotic

docs.title: 17.3.5 Product Copy Rules
docs.text:
• Technical
  • Declarative
  • No warmth
  • No personality
  • Canonical vocabulary only

Examples:

  • “Context Rules”
  • “Policy Engine”
  • “Override Active”

Not acceptable:

  • “Your Tone Settings”
  • “Oops! Something broke”

docs.title: 17.3.6 Motion Behaviors
docs.text:
UI Motion:

  • Hover: 100–150ms
  • Active: 80ms
  • Node pulse: subtle, slow
  • Graph transitions: smooth, directional

Never:

  • bounce
  • elastic easing
  • micro-interactions for “delight”

docs.title: 17.3.7 Product Integrity Audit
docs.text:
Before release:

  • Check component consistency
  • Check spacing uniformity
  • Check semantic clarity
  • Check clarity of technical copy
  • Check graph logic

docs.title: 17.4 Documentation Implementation Playbook
docs.text:
(For specs, API docs, developer docs, whitepapers)

Docs must feel like W3C + Schema.org with Brando identity.

docs.title: 17.4.1 Structure
docs.text:
• Left sidebar navigation
  • Right content panel
  • Lots of negative space

docs.title: 17.4.2 Typography
docs.text:
• Body text: Inter 16px
  • Code: Plex Mono 15px
  • Headings follow modular scale

docs.title: 17.4.3 Content Structure Rules
docs.text: Every doc section must follow:

docs.title: Definition
docs.text: (one declarative sentence)

docs.title: Rules
docs.text: (clear list, minimal)

docs.title: JSON-LD Example
docs.text:
(always present, always valid)

Example:

{
  "@context": "https://brandoschema.com/",
  "@type": "Policy",
  "rule": "tone must match context"
}

docs.title: 17.4.4 Visual Diagrams in Docs
docs.text:
Use:

  • semantic nodes
  • straight edges
  • labels
  • clear grids

Never use:

  • illustrations
  • pseudo-3D graphics
  • icons outside the icon system

docs.title: 17.4.5 Tone
docs.text:
Documentation tone = precise, neutral, technical, standard-like.

Never:

  • conversational phrases
  • emotional tone
  • selling language

docs.title: 17.4.6 Docs Integrity Audit
docs.text:
Check:

  • vocabulary
  • grammar minimalism
  • JSON validity
  • semantic consistency
  • structural clarity

docs.title: 17.5 AI Implementation Playbook
docs.text:
(For LLMs, agents, RAG systems, internal AI workflows)

This is one of the most important sections in the entire brand system. Brando must behave consistently inside AI environments, not just in human-facing materials.

docs.title: 17.5.1 Loading Brando Identity
docs.text:
Every AI workflow must begin by loading:

  • Brando tone
  • Brando canonical vocabulary
  • Semantic narrative hierarchy
  • Content constraints
  • Integrity Audit rules

This is equivalent to activating a Brando Context Node.

docs.title: 17.5.2 Required Prompt Scaffolding
docs.text:
Every system prompt must contain:

  1. Identity Load
  2. Writing Constraints
  3. Semantic Rules
  4. Vocabulary Restrictions
  5. Narrative Hierarchy
  6. Tone Enforcement
  7. Integrity Audit Instructions

(Learnt in Chapter 15 prompts.)

docs.title: 17.5.3 Policy Graph Binding
docs.text: For any AI task involving brand output:

docs.title: The AI must load the Brand Policy Graph first.
docs.text:
Prompts must include:

“Load the Brand Policy Graph before generating content.”

Failure to do this breaks governance.

docs.title: 17.5.4 JSON-LD Generation Standards
docs.text:
• Use only valid BrandoSchema vocabulary
  • No invented properties
  • No synonyms
  • No restructuring
  • No new types unless explicitly approved
  • Always return valid JSON

docs.title: 17.5.5 AI-Driven Semantic Checks
docs.text:
Agents must perform:

  • tone consistency checks
  • vocabulary checks
  • context compliance checks
  • policy compliance checks
  • product/category checks

These checks must map directly to BrandoSchema policies.

docs.title: 17.5.6 AI Reinforcement Rules
docs.text:
If the model drifts:

“Correct the output using Brando’s Integrity Audit.”

Models must self-correct.

docs.title: 17.5.7 Unauthorized Behaviors
docs.text:
AI systems must NOT:

  • generate alternate Brando logos
  • generate novel aurora gradients
  • invent schema terms
  • paraphrase canonical vocabulary
  • produce “friendly” tone
  • produce fluffy marketing language

docs.title: 17.5.8 AI Governance Summary
docs.text:
AI systems must treat Brando’s identity as:

  • a policy to follow
  • a semantic schema to respect
  • a vocabulary to constrain
  • a tone to maintain
  • a structure to replicate

Brando must behave like a standard, not “a style.”

docs.title: Web
docs.text:
• Grid compliant
  • Identity consistent
  • Aurora restrained
  • No off-brand visuals

docs.title: Product
docs.text:
• Component rules followed
  • Semantic graph correct
  • Tone neutral
  • Motion minimal

docs.title: Docs
docs.text:
• JSON-LD valid
  • Structure consistent
  • Vocabulary canonical

docs.title: AI
docs.text:
• Identity loaded
  • Policy graph bound
  • Integrity audit passed

docs.title: 17.7 Chapter Summary
docs.text:
Chapter 17 ensures Brando is implemented consistently across:

  • Web
  • Product UI
  • Documentation
  • AI systems

This is not just design execution — it is machine-actionable governance in practice.

Brando is only as strong as its implementation. These playbooks guarantee precision, structure, and authority everywhere the brand appears.

docs.title: CHAPTER 7 — LAYOUT, GRID & SPACING SYSTEM
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

Brando’s layout system creates structure, clarity, and spatial intelligence. It organizes content the same way the Brand Policy Graph organizes meaning — cleanly, predictably, and semantically.

This chapter defines how space, alignment, and grids are used across all Brando surfaces.

docs.title: 1. Structure first
docs.text: Layout must feel intentional and governed. No randomness, no decoration.

docs.title: 2. Breathe
docs.text: Whitespace is a core asset. It creates calm and premium clarity.

docs.title: 3. Grid-aligned always
docs.text: Everything snaps to grid: text, images, nodes, diagrams, rules.

docs.title: 4. Hierarchy is semantic
docs.text: Important content gets space. Support content stays quiet.

docs.title: 5. Stable compositions
docs.text: Layouts should feel steady, confident, and well-engineered.

docs.title: 6. The visual metaphor = a graph
docs.text: Nodes (content blocks) Edges (flow/relationships) Grid (structure)

docs.title: 7.2 Grid System
docs.text: Brando uses a 12-column responsive grid, with a simplified 8-column variant for product UI.

docs.title: Desktop
docs.text:
• 12 columns
  • Column width: fluid
  • Gutter: 24px
  • Outer margins: 80px
  • Max content width: 1280px

docs.title: Tablet
docs.text:
• 8 columns
  • 16px gutters
  • 48px margins

docs.title: Mobile
docs.text:
• 4 columns
  • 16px gutters
  • 24px margins

This grid mirrors the semantic structure of Brando’s brand: modular, logical, governed.

docs.title: 8-Column Grid (Product UI)
docs.text:
Used in UI for:

  • dashboards
  • schema editors
  • policy graph visualizations
  • forms
  • settings layouts

Configuration:

  • 8 columns
  • 20px gutter
  • 40px margins

This creates a sense of system-level structure.

docs.title: 7.3 Spacing System (Vertical & Horizontal Rhythm)
docs.text: Brando uses a spacing scale in multiples of 8 reflecting modular, technical design systems.

docs.title: Spacing Tokens
docs.text:
• 8
  • 16
  • 24
  • 32
  • 48
  • 72
  • 96

Meaning:

Token Usage 8 micro spacing, label padding 16 text block spacing, simple UI 24 paragraph spacing, minor groups 32 divided sections, multi-element groups 48 section headers, major blocks 72 major sectional separation 96 hero spacing

docs.title: Key rule:
docs.text: Spacing should feel calm, not compressed.

docs.title: 7.4 Vertical Rhythm: Hierarchy in Action
docs.text: Brando layouts follow this rhythm:

docs.title: Headings
docs.text:
• Top spacing: 48px
  • Bottom spacing: 16px

docs.title: Paragraphs
docs.text: • After paragraph: 24px

docs.title: Sections
docs.text: • Separation: 72px

docs.title: Hero Areas
docs.text:
• 96–144px top padding
  • 72–96px bottom padding

This creates a premium editorial grid.

docs.title: 1. Align left by default
docs.text: Left alignment supports readability and precision.

docs.title: 2. Hero text max width:
docs.text: 680px For strong readability.

docs.title: 3. One focal object per frame
docs.text: Never clutter.

docs.title: 4. Semantic grouping
docs.text:
Group related content visually using:

  • spacing
  • alignment
  • subtle dividers

docs.title: 5. Image + text balance
docs.text:
• 60% whitespace
  • 30% text
  • 10% imagery or diagrams

docs.title: 6. No center-aligned body text
docs.text: Unless in a hero moment.

docs.title: Pattern A — Hero
docs.text:
• Aurora gradient or neutral background
  • Headline width ~ 60%
  • Subtitle width ~ 60–65%
  • Semantic node or ribbon subtly placed
  • CTA aligned left or centered depending on mood

docs.title: Pattern B — Text + Diagram
docs.text:
• 6 columns text
  • 6 columns diagram
  • Diagram grid-aligned
  • Ample whitespace on margins

docs.title: Pattern C — Multi-section Narrative
docs.text:
• Sections separated by 72px

  • Alternating:

  • text-heavy

  • image-heavy
  • diagram-heavy

Helps maintain narrative energy without sacrificing clarity.

docs.title: Pattern D — Full-Width Aurora Panel
docs.text:
• Aurora gradient
  • Centered or left-aligned headline
  • Minimal content
  • Single semantic node in focus

Used for:

  • transitions
  • break points
  • high-level vision statements

docs.title: Pattern E — Documentation Layout
docs.text:
• Sidebar (2–3 columns)
  • Content (9–10 columns)
  • All code blocks left-aligned
  • Graph diagrams centered or left-aligned

docs.title: 7.7 Rules for Graph-Based Visuals Within Layout
Nodes
docs.text:
• Snap to grid intersections
  • Never crowd text
  • Maintain consistent spacing between nodes (multiples of 16px)

docs.title: Edges
docs.text:
• 45° or 90°
  • Never curved
  • Never crossing unless semantically necessary
  • Stroke 1–2px

docs.title: Labels
docs.text:
• align above or below nodes
  • use Body S
  • keep text short

docs.title: ✔ DO
docs.text:
• Keep large margins
  • Create airy, premium compositions
  • Use grid alignment religiously
  • Pair structural imagery with neutral backgrounds
  • Apply spacing tokens consistently
  • Use the 12-column grid for marketing
  • Use the 8-column grid for product UI

docs.title: ✖ DON’T
docs.text:
• Overfill the screen
  • Place text directly over detailed imagery
  • Use inconsistent spacing values
  • Break the grid
  • Mix typographic alignment styles in one frame
  • Center-align paragraphs
  • Crowd diagrams

docs.title: 7.9 Layout in the Context of Brando’s Identity
docs.text:
Layout is Brando’s silent governance system. Just as policies guide AI behavior, layout guides the reader’s eye.

Brando layouts must visually express:

  • structure
  • clarity
  • predictability
  • quality
  • semantic order

The grid = the graph. The spacing = the rules. The composition = the meaning.

docs.title: Marketing Page Template
docs.text:
• Hero
  • Value props
  • Diagram section
  • Use cases
  • Proof points
  • CTA

docs.title: Documentation Template
docs.text:
• Left sidebar nav
  • Content
  • Code blocks
  • Graph illustrations

docs.title: Slide Template
docs.text:
• Title bar
  • Wide margins
  • Content blocks
  • Diagram panel

docs.title: LOGO & VISUAL TOKENS — BRAND GUIDELINES (CHAPTER 5)
docs.text: Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

docs.title: 5. Logo & Visual Tokens
docs.text:
Brando’s logo system and visual tokens are built on the core idea of semantic structure — the way rules, meaning, and identity become machine-actionable.

The visual identity must evoke:

  • precision
  • connection
  • structured intelligence
  • the flow of data
  • the elegance of the Northern Lights
  • the clarity of a graph schema

This chapter defines how Brando’s logo and visual system express its role as the standard for semantic brand governance.

docs.title: 5.1 Logo Philosophy
docs.text:
Brando’s logo is not ornamental — it is structural.

It represents:

docs.title: 1. A node in a graph
docs.text: Meaning: identity, entity, brand.

docs.title: 2. A connection between systems
docs.text: Meaning: interoperability, portability.

docs.title: 3. A policy bound as an object
docs.text: Meaning: machine-actionable rules.

docs.title: 4. A stable geometric form
docs.text: Meaning: reliability and governance.

docs.title: 5. Aurora energy (subtle)
docs.text:
Meaning: transformation, semantic flow, activation.

The mark is intentionally minimal, timeless, and technical — it is the visual anchor for a brand built on rules, logic, and clarity.

docs.title: 5.2 Primary Logo
docs.text: The primary Brando logo consists of:

docs.title: A. The Symbol (“The Node Mark”)
docs.text:
A geometric, circular node intersected by one vertical and one horizontal bar, symbolizing:

  • brand identity
  • control points
  • governance layers
  • a “semantic node” in a graph
  • precision & modularity

docs.title: B. The Logotype (“Brando”)
docs.text:
Set in Inter Semi-Bold, custom-kerning for balance and authority.

Letterforms:

  • geometric
  • restrained
  • neutral
  • screen-optimized
  • modern without trendiness

Spacing:

  • wide enough for clarity
  • tight enough to signal confidence
  • avoids excessive friendliness (no rounded tech aesthetic)

docs.title: C. Construction Grid
docs.text:
The logo is built on a 4×4 grid:

  • node diameter: 2 units
  • stroke weight: 0.25 units
  • spacing between symbol & wordmark: 1 unit
  • wordmark height: equal to symbol height

This geometric consistency reinforces Brando’s connection to machine logic and structured design.

docs.title: Primary Lockup (Horizontal)
docs.text: Symbol on the left, logotype on the right. Use in 80%+ of applications.

docs.title: Stacked Lockup (Vertical)
docs.text:
Symbol above logotype. Use for:

  • square orientations
  • center-aligned layouts
  • social media avatars
  • event materials

docs.title: Symbol-Only Mark
docs.text:
Use when:

  • brand is already known
  • within UI
  • as watermark
  • as app icon
  • for favicons
  • for small spaces

docs.title: Logotype-Only
docs.text:
Rare. Use only when:

  • symbol would be redundant
  • text-only contexts
  • compliance documentation

docs.title: Default Logo (Light Mode)
docs.text:
• Symbol: #121212 (near-black)
  • Logotype: #121212

docs.title: Default Logo (Dark Mode)
docs.text:
• Symbol: #FFFFFF
  • Logotype: #FFFFFF

docs.title: Aurora Gradient Logo (Hero Use Only)
docs.text:
Symbol rendered in the official Brando gradient: --brando-gradient

Use cases:

  • keynote slides
  • hero sections
  • product launches
  • category announcements
  • visual storytelling

Never use this for body-level branding. It is a moment, not a standard.

docs.title: Clear Space:
docs.text: Maintain one circle-diameter of padding around the symbol and logotype.

docs.title: Minimum Size:
docs.text:
• Digital: 24px height
  • Print: 7mm height

At smaller sizes, use the symbol-only mark.

docs.title: ❌ Don’t apply drop shadows or glows
❌ Don’t use overly saturated aurora colors
❌ Don’t put the logo inside a shape
❌ Don’t apply gradients except the official aurora gradient
❌ Don’t animate without brand-approved behaviors
docs.text: The Brando mark must remain precise and stable.

docs.title: 5.7 Brand Visual Tokens
docs.text: Visual tokens are the building blocks of Brando’s visual identity — small components that help AI and humans recognize Brando’s semantic system.

docs.title: 5.7.1 Token: Semantic Node
docs.text:
Shape: A circle with a subtle inner stroke, representing:

  • a brand
  • a policy object
  • an entity in a graph

Usage:

  • diagrams
  • UI indicators
  • infographics
  • graph-based visuals

Styling:

  • Fill: neutral or aurora accent
  • Stroke: 1–2px graphite or white
  • Glow: very subtle aurora green or cyan (optional for hero use)

docs.title: 5.7.2 Token: Link / Edge
docs.text:
Straight, clean lines connecting nodes.

Style:

  • 1–2px stroke
  • Neutral or cyan
  • Straight or 45° angles only
  • Never curved or decorative

Symbolizes:

  • rules connecting entities
  • governance flows
  • semantic relationships

docs.title: 5.7.3 Token: Policy Bracket
docs.text:
A thin rectangular bracket shape (similar to { }), representing:

  • machine-readable policies
  • code
  • JSON
  • structure

Use sparingly for:

  • section headers
  • infographics
  • callouts
  • syntax-like ornamentation

docs.title: 5.7.4 Token: Aurora Ribbon (Advanced)
docs.text:
A soft, flowing line with a subtle aurora gradient. Used only for large-format expressive visuals.

Symbolizes:

  • transformation
  • semantic flow
  • AI aligning to brand identity

Never use this in UI or small layouts. Strictly for hero moments.

docs.title: Nodes + Edges (Primary System)
docs.text: These form Brando’s diagrammatic language. Used for policy graphs, semantic diagrams, illustrations.

docs.title: Nodes + Aurora Ribbon (Hero System)
docs.text: Used in marketing and hero sections.

docs.title: Nodes + Policy Brackets (Technical System)
docs.text:
Used in documentation and product UI.

Never mix all three at once.

docs.title: 5.9 Motion Behavior (Optional)
docs.text: When animated:

docs.title: Node Behavior
docs.text:
• slight pulsing
  • micro-scaling
  • minimal glow

docs.title: Edge Behavior
docs.text:
• occasional directional shimmer
  • flow in one direction
  • never looping or chaotic

docs.title: Aurora Ribbon Behavior
docs.text:
• slow gradient shift
  • long, atmospheric easing
  • no fast or sharp movements

Motion must feel stable, intentional, structured — like underlying logic.

docs.title: Formats Provided
docs.text:
• SVG (primary for web)
  • PNG (fallback)
  • EPS / PDF (print)
  • Icon set (symbol-only)
  • Dark/light variants
  • Gradient variants

docs.title: Asset Naming Convention
docs.text:
brando-logo-primary.svg
brando-symbol.svg
brando-logo-stacked.svg
brando-logo-gradient.svg
brando-ui-icon-24.svg
brando-ui-icon-32.svg

docs.title: Access
docs.text: Brand assets should be stored in your central BrandoSchema asset registry with machine-readable metadata for AI usage.

docs.title: Chapter Summary
docs.text:
Brando’s logo and visual tokens express:

  • clarity
  • semantic structure
  • stability
  • the precision of a graph
  • the energy of an aurora
  • the authority of a standard

This system forms the visual backbone for your category-defining identity.

docs.title: CHAPTER 2 — VISION, MISSION & VALUES
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

This chapter defines the strategic foundation of the brand: why Brando exists, the future it aims to create, its mandate, and the values that shape its behavior.

docs.title: 2.1 Vision
docs.text:
A world where every brand has a machine-readable identity — as fundamental and portable as HTML — governing how AI models speak, design, recommend, and act.

This vision positions Brando not as a tool, but as a global standard for semantic brand governance.

docs.title: 2.2 Mission
docs.text:
To create the world’s first and leading standard for machine-actionable brand governance, and empower enterprises to control brand behavior across all AI systems using a portable, open, JSON-LD policy graph.

The mission captures:

  • standardization
  • governance
  • interpretability
  • portability
  • AI alignment to brand identity

docs.title: 2.3 Brand Purpose
docs.text:
(To reaffirm the emotional and functional heart of the brand.)

To give brands a voice in the age of AI — clear, consistent, and unbreakable.

Brando exists to ensure AI systems:

  • represent brands accurately
  • respect their rules
  • protect their identity

Everywhere a model generates.

docs.title: 2.4 Brand Idea
docs.text: Semantic Governance. Brando is the missing layer that tells AI how to behave on behalf of a brand.

docs.title: 2.5 Brand Promise
docs.text: A brand that is understood is a brand that is protected. Brando guarantees both.

docs.title: 2.6 Brand Narrative (Strategic Story)
docs.text:
Brands are losing control in the generative era. AI generates thousands of variations, but it does not know the brand — it only guesses.

The insight: LLMs already understand JSON-LD, meaning the most powerful governance tool already exists.

Brando transforms brand rules into a policy graph, readable by any model. It becomes the semantic layer that governs AI behavior — instantly, portably, and precisely.

This narrative positions Brando as:

  • the HTML of brand governance
  • the standard layer for AI behavior
  • the prescriptive semantic graph for identity

docs.title: Clarity over complexity
docs.text: We simplify what others over-engineer. Clarity is governance.

docs.title: Open over closed
docs.text: Brands should own their governance. Standards must be portable, not locked inside SaaS platforms.

docs.title: Precision over guesswork
docs.text: Machines should never infer a brand — they should be instructed. We design for exact meaning.

docs.title: Brand-first, not model-first
docs.text: We serve brand leaders, not engineers. AI must adapt to the brand, not vice versa.

docs.title: CHAPTER 9 — BRAND MOTION SYSTEM
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

Motion is a core part of Brando’s identity. It represents the flow of meaning, the transfer of semantic rules, and the activation of governance within AI systems.

Brando’s motion system is not decorative animation — it is the visual metaphor for how brand policies move through an LLM.

This chapter defines how movement, transitions, timing, and behavioral cues embody the Brando brand.

docs.title: 9.1 Motion Philosophy
docs.text: Brando motion must always feel:

docs.title: 1. Quietly Intelligent
docs.text: It moves with purpose, not excitement.

docs.title: 2. Controlled
docs.text: Motion reflects governance, not chaos.

docs.title: 3. Semantic
docs.text: Movements symbolize relationships, flows, or activation.

docs.title: 4. Minimal
docs.text: No unnecessary flourish or playful elasticity.

docs.title: 5. Atmospheric
docs.text: Inspired by the Northern Lights — soft, directional, evolving.

docs.title: Principle 1 — Structure Leads
docs.text:
Movement always follows an underlying framework:

  • grid
  • graph
  • path
  • flow

Motion never appears random.

docs.title: Principle 2 — Slow, Calm, Confident
docs.text: Brando avoids sharp acceleration. Motion should be subtle and easing-based.

docs.title: Principle 3 — Direction Matters
docs.text:
Motion implies meaning.

  • Left → Right = progression
  • Bottom → Top = elevation
  • Diagonal (30–45°) = semantic flow
  • Radial Outward = activation
  • Radial Inward = consolidation / policy merging

Never animate downward or chaotically.

docs.title: Principle 4 — Negative Space is Active
docs.text: Movement occurs within ample whitespace. It must feel spacious, breathable, premium.

docs.title: Principle 5 — Aurora Influence
docs.text:
Motion embodies:

  • soft gradients
  • flowing trails
  • luminous shifts
  • atmospheric smoothing

But only in hero or expressive moments.

docs.title: 9.3 Timing System
docs.text: Brando’s timing fundamentals:

docs.title: Durations
docs.text:
• Fast: 120–160ms
  • Standard: 240–320ms
  • Slow: 400–600ms
  • Hero / Atmospheric: 2–6 seconds

docs.title: Easing
docs.text:
• Default: cubic-bezier(0.25, 0.1, 0.25, 1) (standard ease-in-out — calm, controlled)

  • Hero motion: cubic-bezier(0.4, 0.0, 0.2, 1) (smooth and cinematic)

docs.title: Never use:
docs.text:
• bounce
  • spring physics
  • elastic easing
  • overshoot

Brando does not wiggle. Brando glides.

docs.title: 9.4 Motion Behaviors by Element
docs.text: Below are the core motion behaviors applied to Brando’s visual system.

docs.title: 9.4.1 Semantic Nodes (Core Token)
docs.text: Nodes represent entities in a policy graph. Their animation must reflect meaning activation, not decoration.

docs.title: Behaviors
docs.text:
• Pulse: 1–2px expansion, 1.5s loop, 40% opacity fade
  • Glow: Aurora Cyan or Aurora Green soft glow, subtle
  • Connect: When a node links, a line animates between nodes with smooth easing
  • Highlight: 240ms color shift to accent, then settle back

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Never bounce
  • Never jitter
  • Never overshoot

Node behavior = semantic activation.

docs.title: 9.4.2 Edges (Graph Connections)
docs.text: Edges represent relationships and rules.

docs.title: Behaviors
docs.text:
• Draw-In Motion: Line draws from node A → B
  • Directional Shimmer: A faint light moves along the edge to show flow
  • Edge Activation: Slight brightening on interaction (hover/click)

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Always straight
  • Never wavy
  • Never animated in loops
  • Must maintain 45° or 90° pathing

docs.title: 9.4.3 Aurora Ribbon (Hero Element)
docs.text: A soft, atmospheric gradient ribbon inspired by the Northern Lights.

docs.title: Behaviors
docs.text:
• Gradient Drift: Slow shifting colors — 2 to 5 seconds per cycle
  • Soft Parallax: Layers moving at different low speeds
  • Subtle Wave: Very low amplitude sine movement

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• Never fast
  • Never bright neon glow
  • Never occupy the entire screen
  • Use in hero/expressive contexts only

docs.title: 9.4.4 Typography Motion
docs.text:
Typography only moves in:

  • hero moments
  • transitions
  • data explanations

docs.title: Behaviors
docs.text:
• Fade-Up: 180–240ms, smooth opacity
  • Slide-Up 8px: Minor vertical rise with ease
  • Staggered Reveal: 80–100ms per line

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
• No letter-by-letter animation
  • No kinetic typography
  • No bounce
  • No excessive distance

Motion should feel authoritative.

docs.title: Buttons
docs.text:
• Hover: opacity shift + 1px cyan underline
  • Press: slight darkening
  • No scaling

docs.title: Tabs
docs.text:
• Underline slides under selected tab
  • Duration: 200ms

docs.title: Cards
docs.text:
• Soft shadow elevation on hover
  • Max 2–4px rise

docs.title: Modals
docs.text:
• Fade-in: 180ms
  • Fade-out: 160ms
  • No slide-from-top or zoom

docs.title: 9.5 Hero Motion System
docs.text: Hero animations are the most expressive face of Brando.

docs.title: Components:
docs.text:
• Aurora ribbon
  • Semantic nodes
  • Edges
  • Typography

docs.title: Behavior:
docs.text:
• atmospheric drift (2–6 seconds)
  • nodes softly pulsing
  • edges connecting sequentially
  • occasional semantic shimmer
  • text gliding into place

The feeling:

  • intelligent
  • elegant
  • stable
  • futuristic
  • cinematic

docs.title: 9.6 Interaction States & Graph Animations
docs.text: When interacting with the Brand Policy Graph UI:

docs.title: On Hover
docs.text:
• node grows +2px
  • edge brightens slightly
  • label fades in

docs.title: On Click
docs.text:
• node locks to accent color
  • edges animate outward
  • related nodes glow subtly

docs.title: On Filter / Change
docs.text:
• nodes reorganize with 240ms eased transitions
  • edges redraw intelligently

This shows the living structure of the policy graph.

docs.title: ✔ DO
docs.text:
• Use slow atmospheric motion
  • Focus on meaning, not decoration
  • Align motion with graph structure
  • Keep movements subtle
  • Use accent glows sparingly
  • Maintain timing consistency

docs.title: ✖ DON’T
docs.text:
• Use elastic or spring motion
  • Animate text letter-by-letter
  • Flash or flicker
  • Spin elements
  • Overwhelm with gradients
  • Animate every element at once
  • Use cartoon-style movement

docs.title: 9.8 Motion in the Context of Brando’s Identity
docs.text:
Motion expresses:

  • the semantic “flow” of policies
  • the activation of brand rules
  • the stability of governance
  • the elegance of structured meaning
  • the natural intelligence of an aurora

It is a visual representation of how Brando works.

Brando motion is not entertainment. It is explanation.

docs.title: 9.9 Implementation Tokens (CSS/JS)
docs.text: “These are motion primitives for engineers.”

docs.title: CSS Variables
docs.text:
:root {
  --motion-fast: 150ms;
  --motion-standard: 280ms;
  --motion-slow: 480ms;
  --motion-hero: 4s;

  --ease-default: cubic-bezier(0.25, 0.1, 0.25, 1);
  --ease-hero: cubic-bezier(0.4, 0.0, 0.2, 1);
}

docs.title: JavaScript Timing Patterns
docs.text:
const BRANDO_MOTION = {
  fast: 150,
  standard: 280,
  slow: 480,
  hero: 4000,
  ease: "cubic-bezier(0.25, 0.1, 0.25, 1)",
  easeHero: "cubic-bezier(0.4, 0.0, 0.2, 1)",
};

These provide a consistent motion experience across all surfaces.

docs.title: CHAPTER 18 — MULTI-BRAND & PARTNER GOVERNANCE
docs.text:
Enterprise-Level Brand Graph Stewardship Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

Large organizations operate across complex ecosystems: multiple brands, sub-brands, white-label products, co-marketing partnerships, distributors, agencies, and AI platforms.

Chapter 18 defines how Brando governs multi-brand environments, partner interactions, and cross-system identity control. This is essential for large enterprises adopting BrandoSchema and for Brando’s own expanding ecosystem.

Brando is a standard — and standards must govern the full environment.

docs.title: 18.1 Governance Challenges in Multi-Brand Environments
docs.text: Enterprises face specific governance risks:

docs.title: 1. Inconsistent brand voice across sub-brands
docs.text: LLMs blend tone incorrectly across parent/child brands.

docs.title: 2. Conflicting policies
docs.text: Compliance, claims, or legal rules differ between brands.

docs.title: 3. White-label confusion
docs.text: AI systems mix identities for OEM/white-label products.

docs.title: 4. Partner misuse
docs.text: Agencies and distributors produce off-brand content.

docs.title: 5. Multi-region complexity
docs.text: Local adaptations drift from global standards.

docs.title: 6. AI model blending
docs.text:
When multiple brands are loaded, boundaries blur.

Brando solves these with semantic separation, contextual governance, and machine-actionable rules.

docs.title: 18.2 Multi-Brand Governance Model
docs.text:
Brando uses a hierarchical Brand Graph:

Corporate Brand
 ├── Strategic Sub-brands
 │     ├── Product Brands
 │     │     └── Feature Families
 └── Regional Variants

Brando enforces:

  • clear boundaries
  • explicit inheritance rules
  • semantic separation
  • localized overrides
  • policy isolation

Each brand becomes a node with its own:

  • identity
  • contexts
  • policies
  • tokens
  • assets

While inheriting from the parent brand where allowed.

docs.title: 18.3 Brand Inheritance Types
docs.text: There are three inheritance modes:

docs.title: 1. Full Inheritance
docs.text:
Sub-brands use:

  • parent narrative
  • parent tone
  • shared policies
  • shared visual tokens
  • shared governance rules

Used when:

  • The sub-brand is descriptive (e.g., “Brando Governance Cloud”).
  • The identity must remain cohesive.

docs.title: 2. Partial Inheritance
docs.text:
Sub-brands inherit only:

  • tone rules
  • structural rules
  • governance rules

But use unique:

  • messaging
  • color palette
  • contexts
  • product story

Used for:

  • product lines
  • platform modules
  • within-category expansions

docs.title: 3. Isolated Identity
docs.text:
Sub-brand is independent. No inheritance except structural governance.

Used for:

  • consumer-facing brands
  • acquired brands
  • portfolio brands

BrandoSchema encodes these relationships explicitly.

docs.title: 18.4 The Multi-Brand Identity Graph
docs.text:
Every enterprise using Brando should generate a Brand Identity Graph:

brando:Brand
  ├─ brando:hasSubBrand → brando:Brand
  ├─ brando:inheritsFrom → brando:Brand
  ├─ brando:hasPolicy → brando:Policy
  └─ brando:hasContext → brando:Context

This ensures:

  • clear inheritance
  • strict separation
  • consistent governance
  • machine-clarity for LLMs

Brando treats brands as semantic entities, not stylistic variations.

docs.title: 18.5 Multi-Brand Tone Governance
docs.text: AI models often blend tones. Brando prevents this.

docs.title: Rule 1
docs.text: Each brand must have its own tone profile inside its Context nodes.

docs.title: Rule 2
docs.text: LLMs must load only one Brand node at a time. (Multi-brand prompts cause tone mixing.)

docs.title: Rule 3
docs.text: If multiple Brand nodes must be used, prompts must specify the active brand for each output.

docs.title: Rule 4
docs.text: Sub-brand tone must always be derived explicitly — not inferred.

docs.title: 18.6 Multi-Brand Visual Governance
docs.text: To maintain clarity:

docs.title: Allowed
docs.text:
• Shared component system
  • Shared grid
  • Shared spacing
  • Shared typography scale
  • Parent → child inheritance of diagram styles

docs.title: Not Allowed
docs.text:
• Mixing color systems
  • Mixing icon sets
  • Using parent brand aurora gradients in isolated sub-brands
  • Mixing semantic tokens across unrelated brands

Visual governance preserves brand separateness.

docs.title: 18.7 Policy & Compliance Handling Across Brands
docs.text:
Different brands often have different:

  • claim rules
  • compliance requirements
  • region-specific legal constraints

Brando handles this through policies scoped to:

  • brand
  • region
  • category
  • product
  • GTIN

docs.title: Best practice:
docs.text:
Each brand has its own:

  • Policy node
  • Policy graph
  • EffectiveDuring rules
  • Overrides

docs.title: 18.8 Multi-Brand Category Governance
docs.text:
If an enterprise has multiple product lines: e.g., Beauty, Home, Electronics…

Brando ensures:

  • category definitions stay separate
  • GTIN bindings remain isolated
  • product taxonomies do not bleed between brands
  • compliance rules remain category-bound

Allows enterprises to govern complex portfolios.

docs.title: 18.9 Partner Governance Model
docs.text:
Partners must be controlled through governed semantics, not brand trust.

Brando supports three partner types:

docs.title: 1. Strategic Partners (High Trust)
docs.text:
• Access to extended templates
  • Co-branded assets (approved only)
  • Shared governance metadata
  • Access to sub-brand graphs

docs.title: Governance Rules:
docs.text:
• Must use BrandoSchema
  • Must follow vocabulary rules
  • Must not create derivative visuals
  • Must use approved co-branding lockups

docs.title: 2. Agency Partners (Medium Trust)
docs.text:
• Access to primary logo only
  • Strict access to templates
  • No editing of components
  • No aurora customizations
  • No sub-brand creation

docs.title: Copy Rules:
docs.text:
• Must use canonical vocabulary
  • Must follow Brando tone
  • Must be audited before use

docs.title: 3. Integrators / AI Platforms (Low Trust)
docs.text:
• Access to regulated assets only
  • No editable files
  • No raw templates
  • Semantic-only assets (icons, diagrams)

docs.title: LLM Governance Rules:
docs.text:
• Must load the active Brand Policy Graph
  • Must not mix brands
  • Must not invent tone or structure

docs.title: 18.10 Co-Branding Rules
docs.text: Co-branding must follow strict guidelines:

docs.title: Allowed
docs.text:
• Horizontal lockup (Brando left, partner right)
  • Neutral divider line
  • Equal vertical alignment

docs.title: Not Allowed
docs.text:
• Stacked co-branding
  • Blended gradients
  • Custom lockups
  • Mixing icon styles
  • Using Brando’s symbol inside partner visuals

Brando maintains semantic and visual integrity.

docs.title: 18.11 White-Label Product Governance
docs.text: White-labeling introduces identity risk. Brando enforces:

docs.title: Rule 1
docs.text: White-label brand gets its own Brand node.

docs.title: Rule 2
docs.text: It inherits no Brando identity unless explicitly required.

docs.title: Rule 3
docs.text: LLMs must not reference parent brands when generating white-label content.

docs.title: Rule 4
docs.text: GTIN and product bindings must be segregated.

docs.title: 18.12 Multi-Region Brand Governance
docs.text:
Many brands operate across regions with:

  • tone differences
  • daylight claims
  • local compliance

Brando handles this via:

docs.title: Context nodes scoped to:
docs.text:
• geography
  • audience
  • channel
  • regulatory environment

Each context can override:

  • tone
  • claims
  • policies
  • visual expression

Without breaking global identity.

docs.title: 18.13 AI Model Governance Across Multiple Brands
docs.text: AI systems must follow strict sequencing:

docs.title: Step 1 — Load the active Brand node
docs.text: Only one brand at a time.

docs.title: Step 2 — Load brand-specific contexts
docs.text: Tone, region, channel, persona.

docs.title: Step 3 — Load relevant policies
docs.text: Claims, safety, compliance.

docs.title: Step 4 — Bind categories & GTINs
docs.text: Ensure product-level accuracy.

docs.title: Step 5 — Enforce tone and semantic vocabulary
docs.text: No blending across brands.

docs.title: Step 6 — Apply the Integrity Audit
docs.text: Self-check the output.

docs.title: 18.14 Multi-Brand Asset Distribution
docs.text: Each brand receives:

docs.title: Allowed Assets
docs.text:
• logos
  • icons
  • minimal templates
  • semantic diagrams
  • JSON-LD schemas

docs.title: Restricted Assets
docs.text:
• aurora gradients
  • motion assets
  • Brando visual tokens
  • component variants

Enterprises can manage dozens of brands without mixing visual DNA.

docs.title: Brand Identity
docs.text:
• Is the brand’s tone isolated?
  • Are visual tokens correct?
  • Are colors aligned to that brand only?

docs.title: Semantic Clarity
docs.text:
• Are Brand nodes separated?
  • Are contexts scoped?
  • Are policies independent?

docs.title: AI Safety
docs.text:
• Is only one Brand Policy Graph loaded?
  • Are tone and vocabulary constrained?
  • Are overrides respected?

docs.title: Partner Compliance
docs.text:
• Are agencies following templates?
  • Are integrators using sanctioned assets?
  • Are co-brand lockups compliant?

docs.title: Global Consistency
docs.text:
• Are regional contexts correctly applied?
  • Are claims localized without identity drift?

docs.title: 18.16 Chapter Summary
docs.text:
Brando’s multi-brand and partner governance system enables global enterprises to:

  • Maintain strict identity separation
  • Enforce semantic clarity across brands
  • Govern white-label and partner ecosystems
  • Prevent tone blending and identity drift
  • Provide an AI-ready, machine-actionable structure
  • Maintain compliance across regions
  • Extend BrandoSchema without chaos

Brando treats enterprise brand systems like semantic architectures, not visual collections.

This is governance at enterprise scale.

docs.title: CHAPTER 15 — THE COMPLETE BRANDO PROMPT LIBRARY
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0 Prompts for Humans & AI to Generate Brando-Consistent Output

This chapter provides the official, governed prompt library for producing Brando-aligned content across all channels and use cases. These prompts are designed using the rules established in Chapter 14 and the semantic principles defined across the entire brand system.

Every prompt in this chapter is:

  • declarative
  • structured
  • minimal
  • semantically aligned
  • model-agnostic
  • ready for use by humans or AI systems

Brando prompts are not creative instructions. They are governance instructions.

docs.title: 15.1 How to Use This Library
docs.text:
Each prompt:

  • loads Brando’s identity
  • enforces tone, vocabulary, and structure
  • outputs machine-actionable, brand-consistent content
  • prevents drift, fluff, or synonyms
  • applies the Integrity Audit before finalizing output

Prompts are structured as modules, allowing reuse and combination.

docs.title: 15.2 The Core Prompts
docs.text: These are the foundational prompts that all others inherit.

docs.title: 15.2.1 The Brando Master Prompt (Full Identity Load)
docs.text:
(Use for long-form content, docs, web copy, strategic writing)

Prompt:

You must write in Brando’s voice.

Brando’s voice is:
- precise
- semantic
- minimal
- declarative
- authoritative
- calm
- technical
- structured like a standard

Writing rules:
- Use short sentences.
- Use Brando’s canonical vocabulary: semantic, governance, policy graph, machine-actionable, identity, context, precision, consistency, schema, token, GTIN, category, override, lineage.
- Do not invent new terms. Do not use synonyms for Brando concepts.
- Avoid hype, fluff, marketing adjectives, emotional tone, or conversational phrasing.
- Do not use metaphors except in visual or structural contexts.
- Follow the narrative hierarchy: Category → Value → Product.
- Use parallel structure when listing ideas.
- Sound like you are writing a specification, not an advertisement.

Before finalizing, apply Brando’s Integrity Audit:
1. Clarity
2. Semantic accuracy
3. Narrative structure
4. Tone
5. Governance

Now generate the requested content.

docs.title: 15.2.2 The Brando Short Prompt (Quick Identity Load)
docs.text:
(Use for small tasks, short rewrites, UI labels)

Prompt:

Write in Brando’s voice: precise, semantic, minimal, declarative, technical, authoritative. 
Use canonical vocabulary only. No fluff. No synonyms. No marketing tone.

docs.title: 15.2.3 The Brando Rewrite Prompt (Transform Anything into Brando’s Voice)
docs.text:
Prompt:

Rewrite this in Brando’s voice.
Make it precise, semantic, minimal, declarative, technical, and authoritative.
Remove fluff. Remove emotion. Remove marketing tone.
Use canonical vocabulary only.
Follow the category → value → product narrative structure.

docs.title: 15.2.4 The Brando Self-Audit Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Evaluate this content using the Brando Integrity Audit.
Identify deviations. Rewrite to correct them.

docs.title: 15.3.1 Homepage Headline Generator
docs.text:
Prompt:

Generate a homepage headline in Brando’s voice.
The headline must be:
- one sentence
- 6–9 words
- declarative
- category-defining
- precise and minimal
- using canonical vocabulary

Output 5 options.

docs.title: 15.3.2 Section Copy Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Generate a section description for Brando’s website.
Max 50 words.
Follow the narrative hierarchy: Category → Value → Product.
Use short sentences. Use canonical vocabulary only.
Tone must be calm, declarative, semantic, authoritative.

docs.title: 15.3.3 Value Proposition Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Write three value propositions in Brando’s voice.
Each must be one sentence.
Use parallel structure.
Use only canonical vocabulary.

docs.title: 15.3.4 Visual Storytelling Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Generate copy for an aurora-based hero visual.
12–20 words.
Minimal, declarative, semantic.
Use structural metaphor only (flow, precision, governance).

docs.title: 15.4.1 UI Label Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Generate UI labels in Brando’s voice.
Each label must be 1–3 words.
Use technical nouns only.
No verbs. No adjectives.

docs.title: 15.4.2 Feature Description Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Describe this product feature in Brando’s voice.
Max 30 words.
Use technical clarity, not marketing tone.

docs.title: 15.4.3 Tooltip Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Write a tooltip in Brando’s voice.
Max 12 words.
Precise. Technical. Neutral.

docs.title: 15.4.4 Error Message Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Write an error message in Brando’s voice.
Use neutral, precise language.
Avoid blame, emotion, or friendliness.
Max 10 words.

docs.title: 15.5.1 Documentation Section Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Write a documentation section in Brando’s voice.
- Start with a clear definition.
- Follow with rules.
- End with an example in JSON-LD.

docs.title: 15.5.2 JSON-LD Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Generate valid JSON-LD that uses BrandoSchema vocabulary.
Do not invent new properties.
Follow semantic relationships strictly.
Output only JSON-LD.

docs.title: 15.5.3 Technical Explanation Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Explain this concept in Brando’s voice.
Use precise terminology.
Provide structured logic.
Include one example using semantic relationships.

docs.title: 15.6.1 Category Definition Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Define the category "Machine-Actionable Brand Policy Graph" in Brando’s voice.
Use 2–3 short declarative sentences.
Semantic. Minimal. Authoritative.

docs.title: 15.6.2 Problem → Semantic Truth → Resolution Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Write a three-line narrative:
Line 1: State the problem.
Line 2: State the semantic truth.
Line 3: State Brando’s resolution.
Tone must be precise, declarative, minimal.

docs.title: 15.6.3 Semantic Pyramid Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Explain this topic using the Brando narrative pyramid:
Category → Value → Product.
Output 3 short paragraphs, one per level.

docs.title: 15.7.1 LinkedIn Thought Leadership Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Write a LinkedIn post in Brando’s voice.
3–4 short sentences.
Semantic. Declarative. Minimal.
No emojis. No hype.
Use canonical vocabulary.

docs.title: 15.7.2 Micro-Insight Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Write a one-sentence semantic insight in Brando’s voice.
Max 14 words.

docs.title: 15.7.3 “Correct This to Brando Voice” Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Rewrite this social copy in Brando’s voice.
Remove friendliness, hype, and emotion.
Make it semantic, declarative, minimal, and authoritative.

docs.title: 15.8.1 Brand Consistency Checker
docs.text:
Prompt:

Check this content for consistency with Brando’s identity system.
Flag issues. Suggest semantic corrections.

docs.title: 15.8.2 Team Communication Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Write an internal update in Brando’s voice.
Calm, precise, minimal.
No corporate platitudes.

docs.title: 15.8.3 Policy Enforcement Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Describe how this rule should govern AI behavior.
Use clear policy language.
Max 20 words.

docs.title: 15.9.1 Semantic Graph Generator Prompt
docs.text:
Prompt:

Describe a semantic diagram for this concept.
Use nodes, edges, relationships, and labels.
Keep it minimal and governed.

docs.title: 15.9.2 Aurora Visual Prompt (Design)
docs.text:
Prompt:

Generate a visual concept description for designers.
Use aurora language carefully: softness, flow, precision.
No dramatic or emotional language.

docs.title: 15.10 Prompt Composition System
docs.text: Prompts can be combined modularly::

docs.title: Example Composition
docs.text:
• Identity load
  • Task module
  • Constraints module
  • Integrity audit

Template:

[Identity Load]
[Task Instruction]
[Semantic Constraints]
[Structural Constraints]
[Integrity Audit]

docs.title: 15.11 Example: Fully Composed Prompt
docs.text:
Write in Brando’s voice: precise, semantic, minimal, declarative, authoritative.

Task:
Rewrite the following content into Brando’s tone and structure.

Semantic Constraints:
Use canonical vocabulary only.
Do not invent new terms.
Follow the category → value → product narrative.

Structural Constraints:
Use short sentences.
Use parallel structure when appropriate.
Avoid metaphors, hype, or emotion.

Integrity Audit:
Check clarity, semantics, narrative structure, tone, governance.

Begin.

docs.title: 15.12 Chapter Summary
docs.text:
Brando’s prompt library transforms brand governance into machine-actionable instructions. These prompts ensure that, regardless of the model, task, or writer, Brando’s identity remains consistent, semantic, precise, and authoritative.

Prompts are not tools for creativity — they are tools for governance.

docs.title: CHAPTER 13 — SEMANTIC NARRATIVE FRAMEWORK
docs.text:
Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

This chapter defines how Brando communicates meaning across every channel, with a structured approach that mirrors Brando’s own philosophy of semantic clarity and machine-actionable governance.

Brando’s narrative must feel precise, authoritative, minimal, and conceptually clean — always grounded in the logic and structure of the Brand Policy Graph.

docs.title: 13.1 Purpose of the Semantic Narrative Framework
docs.text:
This framework ensures that:

  • Every sentence Brando writes reinforces the category we own
  • Messaging is consistent across all surfaces (website, decks, docs, product UI, social, press)
  • AI systems can reliably reproduce Brando’s tone and messaging
  • Humans and machines interpret Brando the same way

It is not only a writing system — it is a semantic model for narrative.

docs.title: 1. Precision Over Flourish
docs.text: Say exactly what something is and what it does. Avoid metaphor, hype, or ambiguity.

docs.title: 2. Semantic First
docs.text:
Everything should map logically to the concepts of:

  • brand
  • policy
  • graph
  • identity
  • governance
  • semantics

docs.title: 3. Authority Without Aggression
docs.text: Brando speaks as the creator of a standard. Calm confidence > hype.

docs.title: 4. Minimalism
docs.text: We remove everything unnecessary. Short sentences. No filler.

docs.title: 5. Clarity as a Feature
docs.text: Our writing sounds governed.

docs.title: 13.3 The Brando Narrative Pyramid
docs.text:
Brando’s storytelling is structured into three layers:

CATEGORY STORY  (Why Brando exists)
 ↓
VALUE STORY     (What Brando changes)
 ↓
PRODUCT STORY   (How Brando works)

Every piece of communication follows this hierarchy.

docs.title: 13.4 The Category Story (Top Layer)
docs.text: This is the highest-level narrative Brando must consistently reinforce.

docs.title: Brando’s Category:
docs.text: Machine-Actionable Brand Policy Graph

docs.title: Category Narrative:
docs.text:
Brands are losing control in AI environments. Models generate content, recommendations, and actions without understanding brand identity.

The solution is not more guardrails, filters, or fine-tuning. It is a policy graph — a structured, semantic representation of a brand that any AI model can interpret.

LLMs already understand JSON-LD, so the missing piece is not technology — it is defining the standard.

Brando is that standard.

docs.title: Category Messaging Pillars
docs.text:
1. AI must be governed by brand policies, not heuristics.
  2. Brand identity must be machine-readable.
  3. Governance must be portable across every model.
  4. Semantic graphs outperform filters and guesswork.
  5. This is a new category — and Brando leads it.

docs.title: 13.5 The Value Story (Middle Layer)
docs.text: Explains what Brando enables for customers.

docs.title: 1. Control
docs.text: AI behaves according to brand rules — automatically.

docs.title: 2. Consistency
docs.text: Brand tone, content, compliance, and claims stay aligned across channels.

docs.title: 3. Portability
docs.text:
Your Brand Policy Graph works across:

  • OpenAI
  • Claude
  • Llama
  • internal models
  • agents and workflows

No lock-in. No retraining.

docs.title: 4. Speed
docs.text: Deploy in days, not months.

docs.title: 5. Accuracy
docs.text: Semantics > heuristics. Rules are not vibes.

docs.title: 6. Compliance
docs.text: Brand safety becomes policy-driven, not reactive.

docs.title: 13.6 The Product Story (Bottom Layer)
docs.text: How Brando works, explained with clarity.

docs.title: Core Message
docs.text: Brando converts your brand into a machine-actionable graph built in JSON-LD, readable by any LLM.

docs.title: Supporting Messages
docs.text:
• One source of truth
  • Semantic contexts for tone, audience, region
  • Verbal/visual tokens as structured objects
  • Policies encoded as explicit rules
  • Campaign overrides for time-bound changes
  • GTIN and category-level bindings
  • Automation rules triggered by metrics

docs.title: Proof Points
docs.text:
• Built on W3C JSON-LD
  • Vocabulary aligns with Schema.org & GS1
  • Models already interpret the graph natively

docs.title: 13.7 Messaging Matrix (Semantic Model)
docs.text:
Each layer maps to consistent output styles across channels.

Layer Tone Structure Output Examples Category Declarative, visionary Big statements Homepage, keynotes Value Structured, benefit-driven Pillars, lists Marketing site, sales Product Technical, precise Explanation, diagrams Docs, product UI

This matrix ensures messaging consistency anywhere Brando speaks.

docs.title: 13.8 Voice Patterns & Templates
docs.text: Brando uses four sentence patterns, all grounded in semantic clarity.

docs.title: Pattern 1: Declarative Sentence
docs.text:
Short. Exact. Unambiguous.

Examples:

  • AI cannot guess your brand.
  • A brand must be machine-readable.
  • Governance must be portable.

docs.title: Pattern 2: “Problem → Semantic Truth → Solution”
docs.text:
Our most powerful narrative structure.

Example:

  • AI can generate anything, but it doesn’t know your brand.
  • Semantics are the missing layer.
  • Brando makes your brand machine-actionable.

docs.title: Pattern 3: Structured Parallelism
docs.text:
Reinforces clarity and authority.

Example:

  • One standard.
  • One graph.
  • Every model.
  • Consistent behavior.

docs.title: Pattern 4: Policy-Like Language
docs.text:
Sentences that sound governed.

Example:

  • The model must use the Brando Policy Graph before generating content.
  • Brand tone must be consistent with defined contexts.
  • Claims must adhere to policy-level rules.

docs.title: Preferred Vocabulary
docs.text:
• semantic
  • governance
  • policy graph
  • context
  • schema
  • identity
  • precision
  • consistent
  • portable
  • machine-actionable

docs.title: Avoid
docs.text:
• hype tech words (hyper-automation, revolution, synergy)
  • human-centric emotional language
  • metaphors (world of color, creativity unleashed)
  • vague promises (“do more with AI”)

Brando’s voice is crisp and unembellished.

docs.title: ✔ DO
docs.text:
• Use exact terms
  • Write with a sense of calm authority
  • Structure ideas like a graph
  • Use short sentences
  • Favor nouns over adjectives
  • Show logic, not drama

docs.title: ✖ DON’T
docs.text:
• Use playful or expressive marketing language
  • Write long, wandering paragraphs
  • Use fluff (“unleash,” “reimagine,” “unlock”)
  • Make emotional or sensational claims
  • Add personality quirks

docs.title: 13.11 Story Formats
docs.text: Brando uses one narrative framework across all formats.

docs.title: For Website
docs.text: • Category story → value pillars → product proof

docs.title: For Decks
docs.text:
• Category story early
  • Value story in the middle
  • Product story last

docs.title: For Docs
docs.text:
• Product story → schema clarity
  • No marketing phrasing

docs.title: For Social
docs.text:
• Category claims
  • Micro-explanations
  • Semantic snippets

docs.title: Homepage Example
docs.text: AI cannot guess your brand. It must be governed by a policy graph. Brando makes your brand machine-actionable across every model.

docs.title: Product Page Example
docs.text: Brando turns your brand guidelines into a JSON-LD policy graph that LLMs interpret natively. This ensures tone, claims, and compliance stay consistent across all generative systems.

docs.title: Documentation Example
docs.text: The Brand node defines the canonical identity of the brand. Policies are encoded as explicit rule objects. Contexts govern tone and behavior.

docs.title: Keynote Example
docs.text: HTML standardized the web. Brando standardizes brand governance in AI. One graph. Every model. Consistent behavior.

docs.title: 13.13 Narrative Summary
docs.text:
The Semantic Narrative Framework ensures:

  • Brando sounds like a standard
  • Messaging is structured, not stylistic
  • The story is machine-friendly
  • Humans and models receive the same clarity
  • The category narrative stays consistent
  • All surfaces communicate the same identity

Brando’s narrative is not marketing. It is semantic governance in written form.

docs.title: TYPOGRAPHY — BRAND GUIDELINES (CHAPTER 3)
docs.text: Brando Brand Guidelines v1.0

docs.title: 3. Typography
docs.text:
Typography is a core expression of Brando’s identity. It must communicate clarity, precision, authority, and technical excellence — the foundational qualities of the Brand Policy Graph standard.

Brando’s typographic system is intentionally minimalist, engineered for legibility, and designed to reinforce our position as the semantic governance layer for AI.

docs.title: 1. Technical clarity
docs.text: Our type should feel like reading a specification: crisp, exact, and unambiguous.

docs.title: 2. Confidence
docs.text: Brando is a leader creating a new category. Our typography should reflect authority without aggressiveness.

docs.title: 3. Minimalism
docs.text: Whitespace and consistency are part of the brand. Never clutter. Never decorate.

docs.title: 4. Precision & structure
docs.text: Headings and body text follow a strict modular rhythm. Machines understand structure — humans do too.

docs.title: 5. Machine-actionable aesthetics
docs.text: Where possible, the typography should subtly resonate with data, code, structure, and logic.

docs.title: 3.2 Font System Overview
docs.text: Brando uses a two-typeface system, each with a defined purpose:

docs.title: Primary Typeface: Inter
docs.text:
Use for:

  • All brand voice content
  • Website UI
  • Product UI
  • Marketing pages
  • Documentation
  • Long-form writing
  • Presentations and PDFs

Characteristics:

  • Neutral, modern, highly readable
  • Designed for digital environments
  • Legible at all sizes
  • Works harmoniously with grids, spacing, and technical layouts

Available Weights:

  • Light (300) — rarely used
  • Regular (400) — primary reading weight
  • Medium (500) — strong, readable UI
  • Semi-Bold (600) — section headers
  • Bold (700) — hero statements

Use italics sparingly. Inter’s power comes from its clarity, not stylistic flourishes.

docs.title: Secondary Typeface: IBM Plex Mono
docs.text:
Use for:

  • JSON-LD
  • Code blocks
  • Schema examples
  • Technical artefacts
  • Variable names / policy keys
  • Inline references (“machine-actionable”, “policyGraph”, etc.)

Characteristics:

  • Technical without being harsh
  • Clean monospacing
  • Excellent for structured content
  • Supports Brando’s “semantic governance” narrative

Available Weights:

  • Regular (400)
  • Medium (500)

docs.title: 3.3 Modular Type Scale
docs.text:
Brando’s typography follows a Major Third (1.25) modular scale — a rational, elegant set of proportions.

Token Size Weight Usage Display 48px 600 Hero lines, dominant statements H1 36px 600 Page titles H2 30px 600 Section headers H3 24px 500 Subsections H4 20px 500 Group labels Body L 18px 400 Premium reading experiences Body M 16px 400 Default paragraphs Body S 14px 400 Secondary text, descriptions Mono 15px 400 Plex Mono JSON-LD, code Caption 12px 400 Labels, footnotes

This scale ensures consistency, vertical rhythm, and a strong sense of intentionality.

docs.title: Body Line-Height
docs.text: • Body text → 1.5

docs.title: Spacing Rules
docs.text:
• Paragraph spacing: 24px
  • Space above headings: 48px
  • Space below headings: 16px
  • Section-to-section spacing: 72px

This rhythm creates the clean, breathable layouts central to Brando’s visual language.

docs.title: A. Headlines
docs.text:
• Always sentence case
  • Short, declarative, authoritative
  • Never playful or metaphorical
  • Prefer clarity over creativity
  • Use Semi-Bold or Bold only
  • Avoid thin/light weights

Correct:

The standard for machine-actionable brands

Incorrect:

The future of AI brand magic starts here!

docs.title: B. Body Text
docs.text:
• Use Inter Regular (400)
  • Keep paragraphs short (3–5 lines)
  • Avoid idioms, fluff, filler
  • Avoid exclamation marks
  • Maintain a professional tone
  • Prioritise readability

docs.title: C. Technical / JSON-LD Content
docs.text:
Whenever showing anything machine-readable, always use IBM Plex Mono:

{
  "@context": "https://brandoschema.com/",
  "@type": "BrandPolicy",
  "brand": "Brando"
}

Guidelines:

  • Never format JSON in Inter
  • Maintain consistent indentation (2 spaces)
  • Prefer lowercase keys unless schema defines otherwise
  • Avoid inline JSON unless extremely short

docs.title: D. UI / Product Typography
docs.text:
In product UI:

  • Use Inter 14–16px primarily
  • Don’t use exaggerated weight differences
  • Reserve bold text for emphasis only
  • Use Mono for structured data, identifiers, or system labels

docs.title: Do
docs.text:
• Use typography to communicate clarity
  • Lean into whitespace
  • Use monospaced type for any code or data
  • Maintain strict modular scale
  • Use consistent formatting for JSON-LD
  • Prioritize hierarchy

docs.title: Don’t
docs.text:
• Use decorative or stylized fonts
  • Mix too many sizes or weights
  • Add letterspacing to body text
  • Break the modular scale
  • Present code in sans-serif fonts
  • Use italics for emphasis
  • Use “marketing-y” oversized headlines

docs.title: 3.7 Color + Typography Interaction
docs.text: Typography should remain crisp and monochrome.

docs.title: Primary text:
docs.text: #121212 (near-black)

docs.title: Secondary text:
docs.text: #6F6F6F

docs.title: Code block background:
docs.text: #F7F7F7

docs.title: Borders / dividers:
docs.text:
#E0E0E0

Avoid colored text unless it is:

  • an actionable item
  • a link
  • a UI element
  • part of a branded highlight pattern

docs.title: 3.8 CSS Implementation (Token-Based)
docs.text:
For engineering + design consistency, use this CSS token system:

:root {
  --font-primary: "Inter", -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, sans-serif;
  --font-mono: "IBM Plex Mono", monospace;

  --fs-display: 48px;
  --fs-h1: 36px;
  --fs-h2: 30px;
  --fs-h3: 24px;
  --fs-h4: 20px;
  --fs-body-l: 18px;
  --fs-body: 16px;
  --fs-body-s: 14px;
  --fs-mono: 15px;
  --fs-caption: 12px;

  --lh-heading: 1.2;
  --lh-body: 1.5;

  --color-text: #121212;
  --color-text-secondary: #6F6F6F;
  --color-border: #E0E0E0;
  --color-bg-code: #F7F7F7;
}

This allows both designers and engineers to implement typography with precision and consistency across all surfaces.

docs.title: Hero Example
docs.text:
<h1 class="display">Where Brands Govern AI</h1>
<p class="body">Brando turns your brand’s identity into a machine-actionable policy graph.</p>

docs.title: Section Example
docs.text:
<h2 class="h2">Semantic Governance</h2>
<p class="body">
  Brando provides the world’s first portable brand policy graph for generative AI systems.
</p>

docs.title: Code Example
docs.text:
<pre><code>{
  "@type": "Brand",
  "name": "Brando",
  "policyGraph": "enabled"
}</code></pre>

docs.title: 3.10 Typography in the Context of Brando’s Brand Architecture
docs.text:
Typography is not decoration — it is part of the system of meaning.

In Brando:

  • Typography acts as a structural signal
  • It communicates authority, clarity, standards, precision
  • It supports the brand promise of machine-actionable governance
  • It aligns with JSON-LD logic and semantic modelling
  • It makes our content instantly recognizable

Typography is a tool of governance — not style.

docs.title: Brando properties overview
docs.text:
The Brando Schema Vocabulary defines properties (predicates) that attach meaning to:

  • brando:Brand
  • brando:Context
  • brando:BrandExpression and its subclasses (Verbal, Visual, Audio)
  • brando:Policy
  • brando:BrandedCategory
  • brando:Campaign
  • brando:AutomationRule

This page:

  • groups Brando properties by function,
  • explains how domain and range work,
  • and shows how properties combine to form a Brand Knowledge Graph.

For per-property details (domain, range, examples), use the property pages under Schema → Properties in the navigation.

docs.title: 1. How to read Brando properties
docs.text:
Every property in the vocabulary is defined as:

  • an IRI (e.g. brando:toneOfVoice),
  • a type:
    • owl:DatatypeProperty (links a node to a literal value like text or numbers), or
    • owl:ObjectProperty (links a node to another node),
  • a domain (which classes it applies to),
  • a range (what kind of value it points to),
  • an rdfs:comment (normative description in English).

Example (verbal identity):

  • brando:toneOfVoice
    • Type: owl:DatatypeProperty
    • Domain: Brando:VerbalIdentity
    • Range: xsd:string
    • Comment: “Emotional texture and attitude of the brand's voice in this token.”

In JSON-LD:

{
  "@id": "https://example.com/brand/northstar/tokens/verbal/default",
  "@type": "Brando:VerbalIdentity",
  "brando:toneOfVoice": "Calm, empathetic, precise. Explain trade-offs clearly."
}

docs.title: 2. High-level property groups
docs.text:
For implementation and modelling, it is useful to think of Brando properties in functional groups:

  1. Identity & narrative – who the brand is.
  2. Audience & context – who it is speaking to, and where.
  3. Verbal expression – how it speaks.
  4. Visual expression – how it looks.
  5. Audio expression – how it sounds.
  6. Governance & risk – policies and guard rails.
  7. Automation & metrics – rules that react to signals.
  8. Classification & product alignment – GS1/UNSPSC/Google taxonomy.
  9. Files & integration – DAM, Brand OS, and external tools.
  10. Lifecycle & process – enforcement level, review workflows.

The sections below summarise each group and highlight key properties.

docs.title: 3. Identity & narrative properties
docs.text:
Primary domain: brando:Brand Purpose: capture brand strategy and positioning in machine-readable form.

Representative properties:

  • brando:missionStatement Core purpose and day-to-day reason for existing.

  • brando:visionStatement Aspirational future state the brand is working toward.

  • brando:coreValues Foundational principles and beliefs that guide decisions.

  • brando:brandPromise Core commitment or experience the brand guarantees to deliver.

  • brando:brandNarrative Longer-form story describing origin, evolution, and purpose.

  • brando:marketPosition How the brand positions itself relative to alternatives.

  • brando:competitorContext Summary of competitors, adjacent solutions, and differentiation.

Example:

{
  "@id": "https://example.com/brand/northstar",
  "@type": "brando:Brand",
  "schema:name": "Northstar Bank",
  "brando:missionStatement": "Financial clarity with absolute trust.",
  "brando:visionStatement": "Help people feel in control of their financial future.",
  "brando:coreValues": [
    "Clarity over complexity",
    "Do the right thing",
    "Long-term alignment with customers"
  ],
  "brando:brandPromise": "We will always explain the trade-offs clearly before you decide.",
  "brando:marketPosition": "Digital-first bank for risk-aware customers."
}

docs.title: 4. Audience & context properties
docs.text:
Primary domain: brando:Context (some also used on brando:Policy, brando:AutomationRule) Purpose: describe who, where, and under what conditions the brand is active.

Key properties:

  • brando:audienceSegment Strategic grouping of individuals who share relevant needs or characteristics.

  • brando:audiencePersona Persona-style archetypes (“Everyday saver”, “Enterprise buyer”).

  • brando:domainContext Structured JSON-as-string describing channel, surface, region, etc.

  • brando:appliesTo Optional scope for which products, personas, channels this node applies to.

  • brando:effectiveDuring Time window or schedule as JSON-as-string.

Example:

{
  "@id": "https://example.com/brand/northstar/context/retail-chatbot",
  "@type": "brando:Context",
  "brando:audienceSegment": [
    "Retail banking customers",
    "Prospects researching savings accounts"
  ],
  "brando:audiencePersona": [
    "Everyday saver"
  ],
  "brando:domainContext": {
    "channel": "chatbot",
    "surface": "public-website",
    "region": "UK"
  },
  "brando:effectiveDuring": {
    "validFrom": "2025-01-01",
    "validThrough": null
  },
  "brando:appliesTo": "Savings accounts; current accounts"
}

docs.title: 5. Verbal expression properties
docs.text:
Primary domain: Brando:VerbalIdentity Purpose: define how the brand speaks (tone, style, vocabulary).

Core properties:

  • brando:toneOfVoice Emotional texture and attitude of the voice.

  • brando:dialogueStyle Conversational patterns, person/pronoun usage, pacing.

  • brando:writingStyle Grammar, sentence structure, formality.

  • brando:namingConvention How products, features, dates, etc. are named and formatted.

  • brando:personaCard Humanised brand-as-person description.

Vocabulary and messaging:

  • brando:approvedTerms Words and phrases encouraged in this token.

  • brando:prohibitedTerms Words and phrases that must not be used.

  • brando:keyMessages Core value propositions and recurring ideas.

  • brando:tagline Primary tagline plus variants.

Behavioural rules and scaffolds:

  • brando:promptScaffold Reusable instruction block or template for priming LLMs.

  • brando:mustDo Required behaviours.

  • brando:mustNotDo Banned behaviours or constructions.

Example:

{
  "@id": "https://example.com/brand/northstar/tokens/verbal/support",
  "@type": "Brando:VerbalIdentity",
  "brando:toneOfVoice": "Reassuring and efficient. Focus on clear next steps.",
  "brando:dialogueStyle": "Use second person, acknowledge emotion, then move to options.",
  "brando:writingStyle": "Short paragraphs, concrete steps, minimal jargon.",
  "brando:approvedTerms": [
    "interest rate",
    "fees",
    "savings goals"
  ],
  "brando:prohibitedTerms": [
    "get rich quick",
    "guaranteed returns"
  ],
  "brando:keyMessages": [
    "We explain your options clearly before you decide."
  ],
  "brando:promptScaffold": "You are Northstar Bank's support assistant for UK retail customers...",
  "brando:mustDo": [
    "Confirm understanding of the user's question before answering."
  ],
  "brando:mustNotDo": [
    "Do not speculate about regulatory outcomes."
  ]
}

docs.title: 6. Visual expression properties
docs.text:
Primary domain: Brando:VisualIdentity Purpose: define how the brand looks (logos, colours, typography, imagery, motion).

Key properties:

  • brando:brandName How the brand name should appear in visual treatments.

  • brando:logo Canonical URL for the primary logo asset or set.

  • brando:colourPalette Colour system, often encoded as JSON-as-string (roles and values).

  • brando:typography Typography system, often JSON-as-string (families, weights, sizes).

  • Brando:VisualIdentity Design tokens such as spacing, radius, elevation (JSON-as-string).
